The Long Goodbye is a 1973 American crime thriller movie directed by Robert Altman and based on the 1953 novel of the same name by Raymond Chandler. It stars Elliott Gould, Sterling Hayden, Nina Van Pallandt, Jim Bouton, Mark Rydell, Arnold Schwarzenegger and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Benishangul-Gumuz Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

Benishangul-Gumuz is a region in Ethiopia. The capital city is Assosa. The name of the region comes from two local ethnic groups – Berta (also called as Benishangul) and Gumuz.

[[Madeon]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, DJs, Singer-songwriters, French songwriters, French musicians, People from Nantes, Living people

Hugo Pierre Leclercq (born 30 May 1994), better known by his stage name Madeon, is a French DJ, record producer, musician, singer and songwriter from Nantes, Brittany who is currently based in Los Angeles, California, United States.

Leclercq initially came to widespread public attention through a video he uploaded to YouTube, "Pop Culture", where he performed a mash-up of 39 different popular songs in real-time using a Novation Launchpad. The video received millions of views in its first few days of release.

His first EP, The City, was released in 2012.

[[Dire Dawa]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia, 1900s establishments in Africa, 1902 establishments

Dire Dawa is one of two chartered cities in Ethiopia. The other chartered city is Addis Ababa, the capital. It is divided administratively into two woredas, the city proper and the non-urban woreda of Gurgura.

It is on the Dechatu River. The western outskirts of the city are on the Gorro River.

The Dire Dawa University was created in 2006.

[[Subdivisions of Ethiopia]]

CATEGORIES: Ethiopia

Ethiopia is administratively divided into regional states and chartered cities, zones, woreda (districts) and kebele (wards).

[[Stafford railway station]]

CATEGORIES: 1830s establishments in England, 1837 establishments, Railway stations in England, Staffordshire

Stafford railway station is a mainline railway station that serves the market town of Stafford in Staffordshire, England. It is situated on a the junction of the Trent Valley line branch of the West Coast Main Line and the Rugby–Birmingham–Stafford line.

The station is the second busiest in Staffordshire, the busiest being Stoke-on-Trent.

[[Gambela Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

Gambela is a region in Ethiopia. The capital city is also named Gambela.

It is between the Baro and Akobo River. Gambela National Park covers about 15% of the land.

The region is divided into:

[[Harari Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

Harari is a region in Ethiopia. The capital city is Harar. It is the homeland of the Harari people.

[[Somali Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

The Somali Regional State is a region in Ethiopia. The capital city is Jijiga.

[[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Africa, 1994 establishments, Regions of Ethiopia

Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region  is a region in Ethiopia. It is also known as SNNPR. The capital city is Awasa.

[[Arthur Fry]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, American inventors, Scientists from Minneapolis, Minnesota

Arthur Fry (born 19 August 1931) is a retired American inventor and scientist. He is known as the co-creator of the Post-it Note. In 2010, Art Fry was added into the National Inventors Hall of Fame. He was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

[[Fairmont, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota, County seats in Minnesota

Fairmont is a city in and the county seat of  Martin County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 10,666 at the 2010 census.

[[Tigray Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

The Tigray Region is a region in Ethiopia. The capital city is Mekelle. Tigray is the homeland of the Tigrayan, Irob and Kunama peoples.

Tigray has 1 international airport and 4 commercial airports. The international airport is Alula Aba Nega Airport. The 4 commercial airports are Shire Airport, Humera Airport, Dansha Airport, and Axum Atse Yohannes 4th Airport.

[[Joseph S. Pulver Sr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, American novelists, American editors, American poets, Writers from New York, People from Schenectady, New York, Deaths from COPD

Joseph S. Pulver Sr. (July 5, 1955 – April 24, 2020) was an American horror novelist, editor and poet. Pulver Sr. was born in Schenectady, New York. Pulver started his publishing career in the early 1990s. His works focused from Robert Wiene's The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari to H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos and Robert W. Chambers' "King in Yellow". His best known works were Nightmare's Disciple and The Orphan Palace.

Pulver Sr. died at a German hospital of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on April 24, 2020 at the age of 64.

[[Jocelyn Barrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, BBC people, British educators, British activists, Politicians from London, Trinidad and Tobago people, 2020 deaths

Dame Jocelyn Anita Barrow GBR (15 April 1929 – 9 April 2020) was a British educator, community activist and politician. She was the Director for UK Development at Focus Consultancy Ltd. She was the first black woman to be a governor of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) and was founder and Deputy Chair of the Broadcasting Standards Council.

[[Gasoline additives]]

CATEGORIES: Fuel

Gasoline additives increase gasoline's octane rating or act as corrosion inhibitors or lubricants, thus allowing the use of higher compression ratios for greater efficiency and power.

[[Miguel Ángel Troitiño]]

CATEGORIES: Spanish educators, Spanish writers, European geographers, 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Miguel Ángel Troitiño Vinuesa (1947 – 21 April 2020) was a Spanish geographer. He was a professor of human geography at the Complutense University of Madrid (UCM). He was an expert in cultural tourism and heritage preservation. He was born in El Arenal, Ávila, Spain.

He died of COVID-19 on 21 April 2020 in Madrid.

[[Duverger's law]]

CATEGORIES: Voting, Law

In political science, Duverger's law holds that plurality-rule elections (such as first past the post) structured within single-member districts tend to favor a two-party system, whereas "the double ballot majority system and proportional representation tend to favor multipartism".https://www.google.com/search?source=hp&ei=lRulXryMAsilmAXp97vQDg&q=duverger%27s+law+simple+definition&oq=duverger%27s+law+sim&gs_lcp=CgZwc3ktYWIQAxgBMgIIADICCAA6BAgAEAo6CAgAEBYQChAeUN4FWP0tYKI9aABwAHgBgAHxA4gB7g-SAQk2LjQuMS4xLjGYAQCgAQGqAQdnd3Mtd2l6sAEA&sclient=psy-ab

[[Novo-Ogaryovo]]

Novo-Ogaryovo is an estate near Moscow. Since 2000, it has been the residence of Vladimir Putin.

[[The Paper Chase (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books

The Paper Chase is a 1973 American coming of age drama movie. It was directed by James Bridges. The movie is based on the 1971 novel by John Jay Osborn Jr.. Actors include: Timothy Bottoms, Lindsay Wagner, John Houseman, Blair Brown, James Naughton, and Graham Beckel. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox. 

It was nominated for three Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1974. Houseman won for Best Supporting Actor. There was a 1978 television series based on the movie. 

[[Savage Harvest]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 action movies, 1980s adventure movies, 1981 horror movies, American horror movies

Savage Harvest is a 1981 American action adventure horror movie directed by Robert L. Collins and starring Tom Skerritt, Michelle Phillips, Anne-Marie Martin, Derek Partridge, Arthur Malet and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Newman's Law]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 crime movies, 1974 thriller movies, American crime thriller movies

Newman's Law is a 1974 American crime thriller movie directed by Richard T. Heffron and starring George Peppard, Eugene Roche, Roger Robinson, Louis Zorich, Abe Vigoda, David Spielberg, Kip Niven and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[The Marriage of a Young Stockbroker]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 comedy movies, 1971 drama movies, 1970s romance movies, 1970s comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies

The Marriage of a Young Stockbroker is a 1971 American romantic comedy drama movie directed by Lawrence Turman and based on novel of the same name by Charles Webb. It stars Richard Benjamin, Joanna Shimkus, Adam West, Elizabeth Ashley and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[R. P. M.]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Stanley Kramer

R. P. M. is a 1970 American drama movie directed by Stanley Kramer, written by Erich Segal and starring Anthony Quinn, Ann-Margaret, Gary Lockwood, Paul Winfield, Graham Jarvis. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[AtariAge]]

CATEGORIES: Internet, 1998 establishments

AtariAge is a website that is mostly about classic Atari video games. It features gaming news, historical archives, discussion forums, and an online store. It was founded in 1998.

Atari Age is named after the 1982–84 Atari Age magazine. AtariAge also features a searchable database of many things related to Atari video games, including manuals, packaging art, estimated rarity, screenshots, reviews and more, and also an Atari Age magazine archive. A community of homebrew developers for Atari and other classic video game systems is also hosted. Some homebrew games AtariAge published first have been included in official video game compilations, such as Activision Anthology.

[[Slaughterhouse-Five (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 science fiction movies, 1972 comedy movies, American science fiction movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on books

Slaugherhouse-Five is a 1972 American science fiction comedy movie directed by George Roy Hill and based on the novel of the same name by Kurt Vonnegut. It stars Michael Sacks, Ron Leibman, Eugene Roche, Valerie Perrine, Kevin Conway, Roberts Blossom and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Summer Rental]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1980s adventure movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Carl Reiner

Summer Rental is a 1985 American comedy movie directed by Carl Reiner and starring John Candy, Joey Lawrence, Rip Torn, Karen Austin, Kerri Green, John Larroquette. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Plain text]]

CATEGORIES: Computer file formats, Writing

Plain text is textual data. It represents characters of readable material. Plain text is fairly limited because it cannot contain any formatting commands. It is often stored in a plain text file.

[[Summer School (1987 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 comedy movies, 1980s teen comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Carl Reiner

Summer School is a 1987 comedy movie directed by Carl Reiner (who also stars) and starring Mark Harmon, Kirstie Alley, Courtney Thorne-Smith, Dean Cameron. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Neelamperoor Padayani]]

CATEGORIES: Festivals in Asia, Kerala

Neelamperoor Padayani is a Padayani conducting in Neelamperoor Palli Bhagavathi Temple in Neelamperoor, Alappuzha district, Kerala, India.

[[First Monday in October]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 comedy movies, 1981 drama movies, 1980s comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Ronald Neame

First Monday in October is a 1981 American comedy drama movie directed by Ronald Neame and based on the play of the same name by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee. It stars Walter Matthau, Jill Clayburgh, Barnard Hughes, Jan Sterling in her final feature movie role and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Charley Varrick]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s action movies, 1973 crime movies, 1973 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Don Siegel

Charley Varrick is a 1973 American crime action thriller movie. It was directed by Don Siegel. Actors include: Walter Matthau, Andrew Robinson, Joe Don Baker, John Vernon, Felicia Farr. It was distributed by Universal Pictures. The movie is based on the novel The Looters by John H. Reese.

Matthau won the 1974 British Academy of Film and Television Arts Awards for Best Actor in Charley Varrick. In addition, Frank Morriss was nominated for the 1974 BAFTA Award for Best Editing.

[[Earthquake (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s adventure movies, 1974 drama movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Mark Robson

Earthquake is a 1974 American adventure drama movie. It was directed by Mark Robson. Actors include Charlton Heston, Ava Gardner, George Kennedy, Walter Matthau, Geneviève Bujold, Richard Roundtree, Lloyd Nolan, Lorne Greene, and Kip Niven. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

The movie was nominated for 4 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1975. It won for Best Sound. It also received a Special Achievement Academy Award for Visual Effects.

[[Breaking Away]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 comedy movies, 1979 drama movies, 1970s comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Peter Yates

Breaking Away is a 1979 American comedy drama movie. It was directed by Peter Yates. Actors include: Dennis Christopher, Dennis Quaid, Daniel Stern, Jackie Earle Haley, Paul Dooley, and Barbara Barrie. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

The movie was nominated for 5 Oscars in 1980.  It won for Best Original Screenplay. An unsuccessful TV series was made in 1980.

[[History of the World, Part I]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Mel Brooks

History of the World, Part I is a 1981 American comedy movie written and directed by Mel Brooks. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

Mel Brooks also plays 5 roles: Moses, Comicus the stand-up philosopher, Tomás de Torquemada, King Louis XVI, and Jacques. The large group of actors includes: Madeline Kahn, Dom DeLuise, Harvey Korman, Cloris Leachman, Gregory Haines, Sid Caesar, Orson Welles, Spike Milligan. 

The movie was nominated for Worst Picture at the 1981 Stinkers Bad Movie Awards. Roger Ebert gave the movie two stars out of four.

[[Hex (1973 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 horror movies, American horror movies, American western movies

Hex is a 1973 American western horror movie. It was directed by Leo Garen. It starred Keith Carradine, Cristina Raines, Scott Glenn, Gary Busey, Hilary Thompson, and Dan Haggerty. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

Hex played at the Atlanta Film Festival on September 8, 1973. It won the festival's Golden Jury Award. Norman Mailer considered Hex one of the top-ten best movies of 1973.

[[Kolmogorov–Smirnov test]]

CATEGORIES: Statistics

The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is a test from statistics. This test is done either to show that two random variables follow the same distribution, or that one random variable follows a given distribution. It is named after Andrey Kolmogorov and Nikolai Smirnov.

[[Kennebec County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 18th-century establishments in Maine, 1799 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Kennebec County is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census,  the county's population was 121,581. The county seat is Augusta, the state capital. The county was created on February 20, 1799.

[[Knox County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Maine, 1860 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Knox County is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the county's population was 39,736. The county seat is Rockland.

[[Yaka language (Kivu)]]

CATEGORIES: Languages without Glottolog code, Niger-Congo languages

Yaka is a minor Bantu language. It is spoken by some people in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. They mostly live on the north shore of Lake Kivu.

[[Made for Each Other (1971 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 comedy movies, 1970s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies

Made for Each Other is a 1971 American romantic comedy movie directed by Robert B. Bean and stars Paul Sorvino, Renee Taylor, Joseph Bologna, Olympia Dukakis, Candice Azzara, Louis Zorich. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Dreamer (1979 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, American drama movies

Dreamer is a 1979 American sports drama movie directed by Noel Nosseck and starring Tim Matheson, Susan Blakely, Jack Warden, Owen Bush, Pedro Gonzalez Gonzalez, Morgan Farley. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Norma Rae]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Martin Ritt

Norma Rae is a 1979 American political drama movie directed by Martin Ritt and starring Sally Field, Beau Bridges, Ron Leibman, Pat Hingle, Barbara Baxley. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and nominated for 4 Oscars and won 2 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1980.

[[Per Olov Enquist]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Swedish novelists, Swedish journalists

Per Olov Enquist (23 September 1934 – 25 April 2020) was a Swedish author. He worked as a journalist, playwright and novelist. He became well-known around the world with his novel The Visit of the Royal Physician (1999). His awards include Nordic Council Literature Prize (1968), Dobloug Prize (1988), Nelly Sachs Prize (2003) and Swedish Academy Nordic Prize (2010). Some of his works have been translated from Swedish to English by Tiina Nunnally. 

Enquist was born in Hjoggböle, a village in present-day Skellefteå Municipality, Västerbotten. He died on 25 April 2020 in Vaxholm of multiple organ failure. He was 85.

[[Baraigne]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Aude

Baraigne is a commune of 174 people (2017). It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France.

[[Battle of Lade]]

CATEGORIES: Battles

The Battle of Lade was a naval battle which occurred in 494 BC. It was fought between an alliance of the Ionian cities (joined by the Lesbians) and the Persian Empire of Darius the Great. The Persians won the revolt and this led to the end of the war.

[[Giulietto Chiesa]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Former MEPs, Italian journalists, MEPs for Italy, Writers from Piedmont

Giulietto Chiesa (4 September 1940 – 26 April 2020) was an Italian journalist, author, lecturer and politician. He was born in Acqui Terme, Piedmont. He served as a member of the European Parliament from 2004 to 2009.

Chiesa died on 26 April 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Kauko Juhantalo]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Finnish politicians

Kauko Johannes Juhantalo (28 April 1942 – 26 April 2020) was a Finnish politician. He was a member of the Centre Party. He served as a member of the Parliament of Finland many times (1979–1993, 1995–1999, 2003–2007, 2015–2019). He was also Minister of Trade and Industry from 1991 to 1992.

Juhantalo was born in Kankaanpää, Satakunta. He died of cancer on 26 April 2020, two days before his 78th birthday.

[[Fred the Godson]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American rap musicians from New York, American DJs, American hip hop musicians, Musicians from New York City, African-American rappers

Frederick Thomas (February 22, 1985 – April 23, 2020), known as Fred the Godson, was an American DJ and rapper. He was born in The Bronx, New York City. In the early-2010s, he released two mixtapes; his debut was Armageddon in 2010, featuring samples of the Notorious B.I.G., Busta Rhymes, Waka Flocka Flame and Cam'ron. His second release, City of God, was one of a series for DJ Drama’s Gangsta Grillz, and featuring P. Diddy, Pusha T and Raekwon.

Between 2011 and 2020, Thomas released music and performed regularly, guest DJ-ing on New York radio station Hot 97, and worked with artists including Pusha T, Jadakiss, Cam’ron, and Raekwon. He produced two additional mixtapes in 2020, Training Day in January with Jay Pharoah, and Payback, released March 20, 2020.

On April 6, 2020, Thomas was diagnosed with COVID-19 and later suffered from asthma and kidney failure. He died from the infection on April 23, 2020 in The Bronx, aged 41.

[[Val-du-Faby]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Aude

Val-du-Faby is a commune of 562 people (in the year 2017). It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Fa and Rouvenac.

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Aude

Rouvenac is a former commune. It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France. On 1 January 2019, it was merged into the new commune of Val-du-Faby.

Gueytes-et-Labastide is a former commune. It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France. On 1 January 2016, it was merged into the new commune of Val-de-Lambronne.

[[Montlaur, Aude]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Aude

Montlaur is a former commune. It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France. On 1 January 2019, it was merged into the new commune of Val-de-Dagne.

[[Pradelles-en-Val]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Aude

Pradelles-en-Val is a former commune. It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France. On 1 January 2019, it was merged into the new commune of Val-de-Dagne.

[[Roquetaillade]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Aude

Roquetaillade was a commune. It was in Occitanie in the Aude department in south France. On 1 January 2019, it became part of the new commune Roquetaillade-et-Conilhac.

[[Ricardo Brennand]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian businesspeople, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

Ricardo Coimbra de Almeida Brennand (27 May 1927 – 25 April 2020) was a Brazilian businessman, engineer and  art collector. In 2002 he founded the Ricardo Brennand Institute, which includes the world's largest private collection of Frans Post paintings, and was the 17th highest-rated museum in the world according to TripAdvisor in 2014. He was born in Cabo de Santo Agostinho, Brazil.

Brennand died on 25 April 2020 of COVID-19 in Recife, Brazil at the age of 92.

[[Val-de-Dagne]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Aude

Val-de-Dagne is a commune of 739 people (2017). It is in Occitanie in the Aude department in south France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Montlaur and Pradelles-en-Val.

[[Fré Vooys-Bosma]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Aldermen of the Netherlands, Dutch councillors, Dutch women politicians, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, Politicians from The Hague

Fré Vooys-Bosma (30 September 1926 – 25 April 2020) was a Dutch politician. Vooys-Bosma became the first female Labour Party councilor in The Hague in 1982. She retired in 1990.

Fré Vooys-Bosma died in The Hague on 25 April 2020, aged 93.

[[Brugairolles]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Aude

Brugairolles is a commune of 273 people (2017). It is in Occitanie in the Aude department in south France.

[[Kim Chungyum]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors to Japan, South Korean politicians

Kim Chung-yum (김정렴; 3 January 1924 – 25 April 2020) was a South Korean politician. Working for President Park Chung-hee, he was the longest serving chief presidential secretary in South Korean history from 1969 to 1979. He also was Minister of Finance and Minister of Commerce and Industry from in 1966 and from 1967 to 1969. From 1979 to 1980, he was an Ambassador to Japan. Kim was a member of the Democratic Republican Party.

Kim died on 25 April 2020, aged 96.

[[Tomás Balcázar]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican footballers

Tomás Balcázar González (May 4, 1931 – April 26, 2020) was a Mexican footballer. He played as a forward. He played at club level for C.D. Guadalajara from 1948 to 1958 and internationally for Mexico from 1953 to 1954. Balcázar was born in Guadalajara, Mexico.

Balcázar died on April 26, 2020 in Guadalajara, aged 88.

[[Graeme Watson (cricketer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Australia, Australian cricketers, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

Graeme Donald Watson (8 March 1945 – 24 April 2020) was an Australian cricketer. He played in five Tests and two One Day Internationals (ODIs) from 1966 to 1972. He was born in Kew, Victoria. He played for the national team from 1966 to 1972. He also played 18 games of Australian rules football for Melbourne in the Victorian Football League (VFL) in 1965 and 1966.

Watson died on 24 April 2020 of cancer, aged 75.

Lincoln County is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the county's population was 34,457. The county seat is Wiscasset.

[[Bukidnon]]

Bukidnon (Lalawigan sa Bukidnon; Binukid and Higaonon: Probinsya ta Bukidnon) is a province of the Philippines. It is in the Northern Mindanao region. The capital of this province is Malaybalay.

[[Eastern Samar]]

Eastern Samar (Waray-Waray: Sinirangan Samar; Sidlakang Samar) is a province of the Philippines. It is in the Eastern Visayas region. The capital is Borongan.

[[Occipital bone]]

CATEGORIES: Bones

The occipital bone is a bone at the lower back of the skull. At the base of the skull (and the occipital bone) there's a large opening, called foramen magnum, where the spinal chord passes into the skull. 

[[Josephine Hull]]

CATEGORIES: 1877 births, 1957 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, Actors from Massachusetts, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage, People from Newton, Massachusetts, Academy Award winning actors, Golden Globe Award winning actors

Marie Josephine Hull (née Sherwood; January 3, 1877 – March 12, 1957) was an American actress. She won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for the movie Harvey (1950). 

Hull died on March 12, 1957, aged 80, from a cerebral hemorrhage in The Bronx.

[[Harvey (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 comedy movies, 1950 drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Henry Koster, American comedy-drama movies

Harvey is a 1950 American comedy-drama movie based on Mary Chase's play of the same name, directed by Henry Koster. It starred James Stewart and Josephine Hull. The movie is about a man whose best friend is a six-foot-3.5 in. invisible rabbit named Harvey. 

[[Peggy Dow]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Actors from Louisiana, Actors from Mississippi, Actors from Tulsa, Oklahoma, American movie actors, American television actors, American philanthropists

Peggy Dow (born Peggy Josephine Varnadow; March 18, 1928) is an American philanthropist and actress. She was born in Columbia, Mississippi. 

Dow made nine movies, most notably as Nurse Kelly in Harvey (1950), and as Judy Greene in Bright Victory (1951). She also starred as Laura in Reunion in Reno and as Ellen in You Never Can Tell (both 1951).

[[Columbia, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mississippi, County seats in Mississippi

Columbia is a city in Marion County, Mississippi. The population was 6,582 as of the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Marion County.

[[Charli D'Amelio]]

CATEGORIES: People from Norwalk, Connecticut, Living people, American children, 2004 births, American TikTokers, American YouTubers, American dancers

Charli Grace D'Amelio (born May 1, 2004) is an American social media personality and dancer. As of October 11, 2020, she has over 96 million followers on the video sharing app TikTok. She has been called the "reigning queen of TikTok" by the New York Times.

[[All That Jazz]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, 1970s musical movies, American musical movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Bob Fosse

All That Jazz is a 1979 American musical drama movie directed by Bob Fosse and starring Roy Scheider, Jessica Lange, Leland Palmer, Ann Reinking, Cliff Gorman, John Lithgow, Anthony Holland, C. C. H. Pounder, Wallace Shawn. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for 9 Oscars and won 4 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1980.

[[Indo-Islamic architecture]]

CATEGORIES: Architectural styles, Islamic architecture, Architecture of Pakistan

Indo-Islamic architecture (sometimes called Indo-Persian architecture) is a type of architecture and engineering from the Indian subcontinent. Some parts of this type of architecture is similar to architecture from West and Central Asia. In history, Indo-Islamic architecture comes from the time when Islamic empires were in India. It began when Delhi became the capital of the Ghurid dynasty in 1193. Many different dynasties brought in different similarities with Persian and Turkic architecture.

[[American Go Association]]

CATEGORIES: Board games, Organizations based in the United States, Non-profit organizations of the United States, Sports organizations of the United States, 1935 establishments in the United States, Go organizations

The American Go Association (AGA) was founded in 1935, and it is responsible to promote and manage the board game of Go in the United States of America. It is also a member of the International Go Federation.

[[Special Achievement Academy Award]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award categories, 1972 establishments

The Special Achievement Award is an Academy Award. It is given for an achievement that makes an exceptional contribution, but for which there is no yearly award category.

[[1987 Burkinabé coup d'état]]

CATEGORIES: Coups d'état, History of Burkina Faso

The 1987 Burkinabé coup d'état was a coup d'état by the Burkina Faso Armed Forces. It happened on 15 October 1987. It was started by Captain Blaise Compaoré against the President Thomas Sankara, who was his friend. 

[[From Hell to Victory]]

From Hell to Victory (Italian: Contro 4 bandiere, French: De l'enfer à la victoire, Spanish: De Dunkerke a la victoria) is a 1979 Italian Spanish French World War II drama movie directed by Edmondo Amati and Umberto Lenzi. Actors include George Peppard, George Hamilton, Horst Bucholz, Ray Lovelock, Anny Duperey, Lambert Wilson, Jean-Pierre Cassel.

[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s action movies, 2000s adventure movies, 2000 drama movies, 2000s fantasy movies, 2000 romance movies, Academy Award winners, American action movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, American epic movies, American fantasy movies, American romance movies, Columbia Pictures movies, English-language movies, Epic movies, Martial arts movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Ang Lee, Screenplays by James Schamus, Peplum movies, Prequel movies, Taiwanese movies, Hong Kong movies, Chinese movies

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (臥虎藏龍) is a 2000 wuxia movie directed by Ang Lee and written by Wang Hui-ling, James Schamus and Tsai Kuo Jung, based on the Chinese novel by Wang Dulu. The film features an international cast of Chinese actors, including Chow Yun-fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi and Chang Chen.

[[Eat Drink Man Woman]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 comedy-drama movies, Taiwanese movies, Movies directed by Ang Lee

Eat Drink Man Woman (飲食男女) is a 1994 comedy-drama movie. It was directed by Ang Lee. It starred Sihung Lung, Yu-wen Wang, Chien-lien Wu, and Kuei-mei Yang. The movie was released on 3 August 1994. It was both a critical and box office success.

In 1994, the movie received the Asia Pacific Film Festival Award for Best Film. In 1995 it received an Academy Award nomination for Best Foreign Language Film.

Simpson, Susan Flannery. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and Warner Bros. and was nominated for 8 Oscars and won 3 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1975.

[[Phantom of the Paradise]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s musical movies, 1974 horror movies, 1974 comedy movies, American musical movies, American horror movies, American comedy movies, American independent movies

Phantom of the Paradise is a 1974 American rock musical horror comedy movie directed by Brian De Palma and is based on the novels of Gaston Leroux. It stars Rod Serling, William Finley, Paul Williams, Jessica Harper, Gerrit Graham. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was a box office failure and since become a cult movie and was nominated for one Oscar at the Academy Awards in 1975.

[[John Ball (priest)]]

CATEGORIES: 1338 births, 1381 deaths, 14th century in England, English priests, English Roman Catholics, Executed English people, People excommunicated by the Catholic Church, People executed by hanging, People from Hertfordshire, Roman Catholic priests

John Ball (c. 1338 - 15 July 1381) was a Medieval Priest who clashed with the Archbishop of Canterbury after he started performing sermons against Work Service (Serfdom).

Ball was later freed by Wat Tyler and began to persuade peasants to join the Peasants Revolt. Ball was later killed after King Richard II after the Peasants Revolt was put to an end by the king.

It was spun off into the short lived TV series Delta House in 1979.

[[Mood swing]]

CATEGORIES: Human behavior

A mood swing is a quick change in mood. These can promote problem solving and in producing flexible forward planning. However, when mood swings are so strong that they become unhelpful, they may be the main part of a bipolar disorder.

[[Buckypaper]]

CATEGORIES: Carbon compounds, Nanotechnology

Buckypaper is a thin sheet made from an aggregate of carbon nanotubes or carbon nanotube grid paper. The nanotubes are approximately 50,000 times thinner than a human hair. Originally, it was fabricated as a way to handle carbon nanotubes, but it is also being studied and developed into applications by several research groups, showing promise as vehicle armor, personal armor, and next-generation electronics and displays.

[[Rouge]]

CATEGORIES: Musical groups established in 2002, Musical groups disestablished in 2006, Musical quintets

Rouge are a Brazilian pop girl group formed in 2002, through the SBT and Disney Channel talent show Popstars produced by RGB Entertainment. The group comprised singers Aline Wirley, Fantine Thó, Karin Hils, Li Martins (then known as Patrícia Lissah) and Lu Andrade.

The group's debut studio album, the best-selling self-titled Rouge (2002), sold more than 2 million copies in Brazil. The success of the album was boosted by the songs "Não Dá pra Resistir", "Beijo Molhado" and, mainly, "Ragatanga", which helped to establish the group on a national platform. Their follow-up album, C'est La Vie (2003) produced the singles "Brilha La Luna", "Um Anjo Veio Me Falar" and "Vem Cair na Zueira", sold over 1 million copies. After the departure of Andrade, the four remaining members continued and released the albums Blá Blá Blá (2004) and Mil e Uma Noites (2005). The group disbanded in June 2006, when the contract with Sony Music was not renewed.

Measures of their success include, have sold 6 million records sales, becoming the most successful pop girl group in Brazil and Latin America, Under the guidance of their mentor and entrepreneur, music producer Rick Bonadio, they embarked on sold-out tours throughout Brazil and several countries in Latin America, Europe and Africa. They were also stars of commercials and television programs, as well as the faces of various licensed products such as sticker albums, sandals and dolls.

On September 12, 2017, they reformed for a second time, this time as a five-members, to celebrate a fifteen-year birthday, embarked on a tour of sold-out shows all over Brazil, the 15 Anos Tour. In followed, he released his first unreleased song since 2005, "Bailando". And, on February 1, 2019 the fifth studio album, Les 5inq, was released.  On January 24, 2019, a new hiatus was announced for an indefinite time. It is unknown if Rouge will reunite after this new hiatus.
