[[Province of New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: 17th century in North America, 18th century in New Jersey, Former British colonies

The first people to live on the land now known as New Jersey were the Delaware Indians. They lived here starting at least 10,000 years ago. Anywhere from 8,000 to 20,000 Delaware Indians lived in the area when the first Europeans arrived. Their name means "original people" or "genuine people." They spoke an Algonquian dialect.

Though they were considered one tribe, the Delaware Indians didn't act as one unified group. Instead, they lived in small communities made up mostly of extended family members. The men would hunt or fish during the day. Depending on the season they might search for clams off the Jersey shore or hunt in the woods. The women worked in the gardens. They grew squash, beans, sweet potatoes, and corn.

When the first explorers came, the Delaware Indians lived in parts of Delaware, New Jersey, and eastern Pennsylvania. Europeans called them the Delaware Indians.

[[Keizo Yamada]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese sportspeople, Olympians

Keizo Yamada was a Japanese long-distance runner. He won the 1956 edition of the Fukuoka Marathon. He represented Japan at the 1952 Summer Olympics, finishing in 26th place (2:38:11) and won the 1953 Boston Marathon. He was born in Akita.

[[Carlo Sabatini (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian voice actors, Actors from Rome

Carlo Sabatini (7 April 1932 – 10 April 2020) was an Italian actor. He was born in Rome. He was known for voice dubbing movie roles of Morgan Freeman and Sir Ian McKellen from English to Italian. He voiced dubbed Magneto in X-Men, X2, X-Men: The Last Stand, The Wolverine, and X-Men: Days of Future Past.

Sabatini died on 10 April 2020 in Rome, aged 88.

[[Lucas Neff]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Chicago, Living people

Lucas Neff (born November 7, 1985) is an American actor. He is best known for his lead role in the Fox sitcom Raising Hope, and starred on the CBS sitcom Carol's Second Act.

Neff was born and raised in the Andersonville area of Chicago, Illinois. He is of Irish and Jewish descent.

[[Gregg Binkley]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, American television actors, Actors from Kansas, People from Topeka, Kansas, Living people

Gregg Binkley (born March 20, 1963) is an American television actor. He is best known for his roles as Kenny James on the NBC sitcom My Name Is Earl and as Dan, the Del Taco spokesperson. He has also had guest spots on Gilmore Girls, Malcolm in the Middle, Sabrina, the Teenage Witch, Yes, Dear, The Drew Carey Show, Full House, and Wizards of Waverly Place.

[[Bruce Allpress]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, New Zealand movie actors, New Zealand television actors

Bruce Robert Allpress (25 August 1930 – 23 April 2020) was a New Zealand actor. He appeared in many television dramas and also presented on television and radio productions. In the mid-1980s, he was a regular on The Billy T. James Show, as well as featuring alongside Tommy Lee Jones in the pirate adventure movie Nate and Hayes. He was best known for his role as Aldor in the movie The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers.

Allpress died on 23 April 2020, aged 89, in Auckland six months after being diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

[[Alan Abel (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American inventors, American educators, Musicians from Indiana, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Alan Abel (1928 – April 25, 2020) was an American percussionist, music educator, and inventor. He was the Associate Principal Percussionist of the Philadelphia Orchestra from 1959 until his retirement in 1997. He taught at Temple University beginning in 1972.  

Abel died on April 25, 2020 from COVID-19.

[[Thomas Huang]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Chinese scientists, Engineers from Illinois, American computer scientists, Scientists from Illinois

Thomas Shi-Tao Huang (t, June 26, 1936 – April 25, 2020) was a Chinese-born American electrical engineer and computer scientist. He was a researcher and professor emeritus at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). Huang was one of the important scientist in computer vision, pattern recognition and human computer interaction. Huang was born June 26, 1936, in Shanghai, Republic of China.

[[Emilio S. Allué]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Spanish Roman Catholics, American Roman Catholics, Bishops, People from Boston, Massachusetts

Emilio Simeon Allué Carcasona, SDB (18 February 1935 – 26 April 2020) was a Spanish-American prelate of the Catholic Church. He was an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of Boston until his retirement in 2010. He was born in Huesca, Spain.

Allué died from COVID-19 in Boston on 26 April 2020, aged 85.

[[Big Al Carson]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American blues singers, Singers from New Orleans, Louisiana, American jazz singers, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana

Alton "Big Al" Carson (October 2, 1953 – April 26, 2020) was an American blues and jazz singer. He performed with his band, the Blues Masters, in New Orleans, and with other bands. He was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. He played tuba in addition to singing.  Carson performed and recorded with multiple jazz and brass bands in New Orleans, including under the leadership of Doc Paulin, Lars Edegran, and Dr. Michael White.

Carson died on April 26, 2020 at the age of 66 after a heart attack in New Orleans.

[[Gideon Patt]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Former Members of Knesset, Government ministers of Israel, Jewish Israeli politicians, Likud politicians, People from Jerusalem

Gideon Patt (גדעון פת; 22 February 1933 – 26 April 2020) was an Israeli politician. He was born in Jerusalem. Patt was a member of the Knesset from 1970 to 1996. He was a Minister of Industry from 1979 to 1984 and Tourism in 1981 and again from 1988 to 1992. He was a member of Likud.

Patt died on 26 April 2020 in Jerusalem at the age of 87.

[[Henri Weber]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, Former MEPs, Jewish French politicians, MEPs for France, Polish Jews, Socialist Party (France) politicians

Henri Weber (23 June 1944 – 26 April 2020) was a French politician of Jewish-Polish descent. He was a Member of the European Parliament for the north-west of France from 2004 to 2014. He was a member of the Socialist Party (PS). From 1995 to 2004, Weber was a member of the French Senate. His father-in-law was politician Jean-Claude Servan-Schreiber.

Weber died on 26 April in 2020 in Avignon of COVID-19, aged 75.

[[Bernard Gersten]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winners, 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cancer deaths in New York City, Businesspeople from Newark, New Jersey, Businesspeople from New York City

Bernard Gersten (January 30, 1923 – April 27, 2020) was an American theatrical producer. His career began in the 1960s through the early 2000s. He was born in Newark, New Jersey. From 1960 to 1978, Gersten worked with Joseph Papp as associate producer at the New York Shakespeare Festival. He was an executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater from 1986 until he retired in 2013. In 2013, he won a Special Tony Award.

Gersten died from pancreatic cancer in New York City on April 27, 2020, aged 97.

[[Ramon Jimenez Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: People from Manila, Filipino politicians, Filipino businesspeople, 1955 births, 2020 deaths

Ramon Reyes Jimenez Jr. (July 14, 1955 – April 27, 2020) sometimes known as Monet or Mon Jimenez, was a Filipino advertising businessman and politician. He was Secretary of Tourism from 2011 to 2016 during the presidency of Benigno Aquino III. He was born in Manila.

Jimenez died on April 27, 2020 in Manila, aged 64.

[[Tiede Herrema]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch businesspeople

Dr Tiede Herrema (21 April 1921 – 24 April 2020) was a Dutch businessman. He was kidnapped by the Provisional Irish Republican Army in 1975. He was born in present-day Utrecht.

In the 1970s, Herrema ran a wire factory, Ferenka, in the city of Limerick, Ireland. On the morning of 3 October 1975, having just left his home in Castletroy near Limerick, Herrema was kidnapped by two members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army. The kidnappers wanted the release of three IRA prisoners, including Rose Dugdale.

After a massive security operation, the kidnappers were eventually traced on 21 October 1975 to a house in Monasterevin, County Kildare. After a further two-week-long struggle, Herrema was released.

Herrema died on 24 April 2020, three days after his 99th birthday.

[[Rob Shick]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Ice hockey people from British Columbia, National Hockey League, Referees

Rob Shick (born 4 December 1957 in Port Alberni, British Columbia) is a retired National Hockey League referee. He began his career with the 1985–86 NHL season. He retired in March 2009. 

[[Birbhum district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of West Bengal

Birbhum district is a district in West Bengal, India.

[[Central Division, Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Divisions of Fiji

The Central Division is one of four divisions in Fiji. The capital of the division is Suva, which is also the capital of Fiji.

It has five provinces - Naitasiri, Namosi, Rewa, Serua and Tailevu. The division includes the eastern part of the largest island in Fiji, Viti Levu. There are also a few outlying islands, including Beqa.

[[Eastern Division, Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Divisions of Fiji

The Eastern Division is one of four divisions in Fiji. The capital of the division is Levuka, on the Ovalau island. 

It has Kadavu Province, Lau Province, Lomaiviti Province and Rotuma. Other islands in the division include Kadavu, Gau, Koro, Nairai, Moala, Matuku, Vatu Vara, Naitaba, Mago, Cicia, Tuvuca, Lakeba, Vanua Vatu, Oneata, Vuaqava, Kabara, Moce, and Fulaga.

[[Northern Division, Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Divisions of Fiji

The Northern Division is one of four divisions in Fiji. The capital is Labasa.

The Northern Division has three Provinces: Macuata, Cakaudrove, and Bua. It includes the entire island of Vanua Levu.

[[Western Division, Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Divisions of Fiji

The Western Division is one of four divisions in Fiji. The largest city is Lautoka.

There are three provinces on Viti Levu. They are Ba, Nadroga-Navosa and Ra. It also includes a few outlying islands, including the Yasawa Islands, Viwa Island, and Mamanuca Islands.

[[Ba Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Ba is a province in Fiji. It is in the Western Division. It is on Viti Levu, Fiji's largest island. 

There were about 245,000 people living there in 2017, the most of any province. It covers a land area of 2634.

Ba Province includes the towns and districts of Ba, Magodro, Nadi, Nawaka, Tavua, Vuda and Vitogo.  The city of Lautoka and the Yasawa Archipelago are also in Ba Province.

[[Nadroga-Navosa Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Nadroga-Navosa is a province in Fiji. It is on Viti Levu, Fiji's largest island. The main town is Sigatoka. The province includes the Mamanuca Archipelago as well as Conway Reef.

The Sigatoka Sand Dunes, a World Heritage Site, is in the province. In July 1989, the dunes were made Fiji's first national park.

[[Ra Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Ra is one of the fourteen provinces in Fiji. It is in the Western Division. It is on Viti Levu, the largest island. The main town is Vaileka.

Ra has a land area of 1341 square kilometers. About 30,000 people lived there in 2017. There are 19 districts.

[[Macuata Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Macuata is one of fourteen  Provinces in Fiji. It is on the island of Vanua Levu in the Northern Division. The main town is Labasa.

Macuata has a land area of 2004 square kilometers. About 66,000 people lived there in 2017. The Province has 114 villages spread over 12 districts. 

[[Silent Circle (band)]]

CATEGORIES: German pop music groups, German pop singers

Silent Circle is a German eurodisco band formed in 1985 by Martin Tychsen and Axel Breitung. it features from German-language dubbed version Nutri Ventures uses the song called Touch In The Night as the main theme.

[[Cakaudrove Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Cakaudrove is a province in Fiji. It is on the island of Vanua Levu in the Northern Division. The province includes the islands of Taveuni, Rabi, Kioa, and many other islands in the Vanua Levu Group. The only major town is Savusavu.

It has a total land area of 2,816 square kilometers. About 50,000 people lived there in 2017.

[[Bua Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Bua is a province in Fiji. It is on the island of Vanua Levu in the Northern Division.

It has a land area of 1,379 square kilometers. About 15,500 people lived there in 2017.

[[Kadavu Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Kadavu Province is a province in Fiji. It is in the Eastern Division. It has Kadavu Island, Ono Island, Galoa Island, Dravuni Island, Matanuku Island, Buliya Island, Nagigia Island, and a few other islands.

Kadavu has a total land area of 478 square kilometers. About 11,000 people lived there in 2017. There are 9 districts.

Kadavu is home to the second-largest living organism on Earth, the Great Astrolabe Reef.

[[Lau Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Lau Province is a province in Fiji. The capital is Tubou, at the southern end of the island of Lakeba. Lau is in the Eastern Division. The province includes the Lau Islands. The island group has about 60 islands.

It has a total land area of 487 square kilometers. About 9,600 people lived there in 2017. 

[[Deliberative assembly]]

CATEGORIES: government

A deliberative assembly is a group of members (of any kind of bigger group) who use parliamentary procedure to make decisions.

[[Lomaiviti Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Lomaiviti Province is a province of Fiji. It is part of the Eastern Division. It is made up of the Lomaiviti Islands. The largest town is Levuka.

The province has a total land area of 41 square kilometers. About 15,600 people lived there in 2017.

[[Naitasiri Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Naitasiri is one of the 14 provinces of Fiji. It is on Viti Levu, Fiji's largest island. It is part of the Central Division.

Naitasiri has an area of 1,666. About 178,000 people lived there in 2017. The main town is Nasinu.

The Medrausucu mountain ranges are in the province.

[[Namosi Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Namosi is a province in Fiji. It is on Viti Levu, the largest island. It is part of the Central Division.

The province covers 570 square kilometers. About 7,800 people lived there in 2017. Namosi Province includes Namosi District, as well as the districts of Veivatuloa and Wainikoroiluva.

[[Rewa Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Rewa is a province in Fiji. It includes the capital city of Suva.

It has a land area of 272 square kilometers, making it the smallest province in Fiji. About 108,000 people lived there in 2017.

The province has nine tikina (or districts):

[[Serua Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Serua is a province in Fiji. It is on Viti Levu, the largest island of Fiji. It is part of the Central Division.

It has a land area of 830 square kilometers. About 15,400 people lived there in 2017. Serua includes Nuku District and Serua District.

[[Tailevu Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Fiji

Tailevu is a province in Fiji. It is on Viti Levu, Fiji's largest island. It is part of the Central Division. The main town is Nausori.

Tailevu has a land area of 755 square kilometers. About 64,500 people lived there in 2017. Tailevu has the districts of Bau, Nakelo, Verata, Wainibuka, and Sawakasa.

[[Victory Is Mine]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 movies, 1956 drama movies, Japanese movies, Movies directed by Seijun Suzuki

Victory Is Mine is a 1956 Japanese drama movie directed by first time director Seijun Suzuki and stars Kō Mishima, Shinsuke Maki, Sumiko Minami, Keiko Amaji. It was distributed by Nikkatsu.

[[Portapique]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Nova Scotia

Portapique is a small community in Nova Scotia, Canada in Colchester County.

In April 2020, it was one of the places where the 2020 Nova Scotia attacks happened, which was the deadliest massacre in Canadian history.

[[Gorakhpur]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Uttar Pradesh

Gorakhpur is a city in the north-eastern region of Uttar Pradesh state of India. It is the administrative headquarters of Gorakhpur district. The city is home to the Gorakhnath Math, a Gorakhnath temple. The city also has an Indian Air Force station, since 1963. According to 2011 Indian Census, Gorakhpur had a total population of 673,446, of which 353,907 were males and 319,539 were females.

[[Wentworth, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Nova Scotia

Wentworth is a community in Nova Scotia, Canada in Wentworth Valley in Cumberland County.

In April 2020, it was one of the places where the 2020 Nova Scotia attacks happened, which was the deadliest massacre in Canadian history. Four were killed in Wentworth.

[[Mata Hari (1985 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 drama movies, 1980s erotic movies, 1980s biographical movies, American drama movies

Mata Hari is a 1985 American erotic biographic drama movie directed by Curtis Harrington and stars Sylvia Kristel, Oliver Tobias, Christopher Cazonove. It was distributed by Cannon Pictures.

[[Debert]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Nova Scotia

Debert is an unincorporated community in Nova Scotia, Canada. It is in Colchester County. In 2006, 1,471 people lived here.

[[Enfield, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Nova Scotia

Enfield is a community that is 5 north of Halifax Stanfield International Airport in the Shubenacadie Valley in Nova Scotia, Canada. It is in both Hants and Halifax counties.

[[On the Right Track]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 comedy movies, American comedy movies

On the Right Track is a 1981 American comedy movie directed by Lee Philips and starring Gary Coleman, Kim Basinger, Norman Fell, Bill Russell, Lisa Eilbacher. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Pixote]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 movies, 1980s crime drama movies, 1980s LGBT movies, Brazilian movies, Movies directed by Héctor Babenco

Pixote: a Lei do Mais Franco (piˈʃɔtʃi a ˈlej du ˈmajʃ ˈfɾaku, lit. "Pixote (small child): The Law of the Weakest") is a 1981 Brazilian drama movie directed by Héctor Babenco and based on the novel A Infância dos Mortos (The Childhood of the Dead Ones) by José Louzeiro. It stars Fernando Ramos de Silva as the title character.

[[Bloodbath]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 horror movies, Spanish movies, Liechtenstein movies, Movies directed by Silvio Narizzano

Bloodbath, also known as Las Flores Del Vicio (English: The Flowers of Vice) and The Sky is Falling, is a 1979 Spanish Liechtenstein horror movie directed by Silvio Narizzano and starring Carroll Baker, Dennis Hopper, Richard Todd, Faith Brook.

[[Lloyd deMause]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American historians, American psychologists, Writers from Detroit, Michigan, Scientists from Detroit, Michigan

Lloyd deMause (pronounced de-Moss; September 19, 1931 – April 23, 2020) was an American social thinker. He was known for his works in psychohistory. He did graduate work in political science at Columbia University. He became a psychoanalyst afterwards. He was the founder of The Journal of Psychohistory.

[[Suddenly, Last Summer]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 drama movies, American drama movies, British drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz

Suddenly, Last Summer is a 1959 British American psychological drama movie directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and based on the play of the same name by Tennessee Williams. It stars Elizabeth Taylor, Katharine Hepburn, Montgomery Clift, Albert Dekker and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 3 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1960.

[[Carlos Regazzoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine sculptors

Carlos Regazzoni (1 December 1943 – 26 April 2020) was an Argentine sculptor. Regazzoni was born in Comodoro Rivadavia, Chubut Province. He worked in Paris during the 1990s. He was invited to exhibit at the Cent ans de l'aéronautique française. Regazzoni returned to Argentina and founded a workshop in Buenos Aires. His works were often described as Dantesque and were compared to Salvador Dali.

Regazzoni died on 26 April 2020 in Buenos Aires, aged 76.

[[Robert Herbin]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Sportspeople from Paris, French footballers, French football managers

Robert Herbin (30 March 1939 – 27 April 2020) was a French football defender and manager. He was born in Paris. He played for Saint-Étienne and the national team. He managed Saint-Étienne and Red Star F.C. 93.

Herbin died on 27 April 2020 in Saint-Étienne, France of heart failure at the age of 81.

[[Troy Sneed]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American singer-songwriters, American gospel singers, Singers from Florida, Writers from Florida

Troy Lenard Sneed, Jr. (December 14, 1967 – April 27, 2020) was an American gosep singer-songwriter. He was born in Perry, Florida. 

He started his music career on November 7, 1999, with the release of Call Jesus by Malaco Records. His second album, Bless That Wonderful Name, was released by Savoy Records in 2001. The third album, A State of Worship, was released and was a hit with Billboard magazine Gospel Albums chart. His fourth release, In His Presence, was released in 2006. The fifth album from him, In Due Season, was released in 2009. He released the sixth album in 2011, My Heart Says Yes. His seventh album, All Is Well, released in 2012.

Sneed died on April 27, 2020 in Jacksonville, Florida of COVID-19, aged 52.

[[Jamilur Reza Choudhury]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Bangladeshi people, Bangladeshi educators, Engineers, Researchers, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Jamilur Reza Choudhury (15 November 1943 – 28 April 2020) was a Bangladeshi civil engineer, professor, researcher, and educator. He was an Adviser (Minister) to Caretaker Government of Bangladesh (April–June 1996). He was the vice chancellor of BRAC University from 2001 to 2012 and of University of Asia Pacific from 2012 until his death. He was also the president of Bangladesh Mathematical Olympiad Committee from 2003.

He was awarded Ekushey Padak by the Government of Bangladesh in the category of science and technology in 2017. He was made a National Professor by the Government of Bangladesh in 2018.

Choudhury died on 28 April 2020 of heart attack in Dhaka, aged 76.

[[John E. Otto]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Politicians from Saint Paul, Minnesota

John E. Otto (December 18, 1938 – April 22, 2020) was an American government official. He was the Acting Director of the FBI in 1987.

Otto died on April 22, 2020 in Norman, Oklahoma at the age of 81.

[[Clyde Tolson]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1975 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Politicians from Missouri

Clyde Anderson Tolson (May 22, 1900 – April 14, 1975) was the second-ranking official of the FBI from 1930 until 1972. He is best known as the protégé and long time top deputy of FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover. He was Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for one day in May 1972.

[[Laredo, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Laredo is a city in Grundy County, Missouri, United States. The population was 198 at the 2010 census.

[[L. Patrick Gray]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2005 deaths, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, US Republican Party politicians

Louis Patrick Gray III (July 18, 1916 – July 6, 2005) was Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) from May 2, 1972 to April 27, 1973. He was in charge of the initial investigation into the burglaries that sparked the Watergate scandal, which eventually led to the resignation of President Nixon. 

Gray was nominated as permanent Director by Nixon on February 15, 1973, but failed to win Senate confirmation. He resigned as Acting FBI director on April 27, 1973, after he admitted to destroying documents from Watergate.

Gray remained publicly silent about the Watergate scandal for 32 years, speaking to the press only once, near the end of his life.

[[Clarence M. Kelley]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1997 deaths, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Politicians from Kansas City, Missouri, US Republican Party politicians

Clarence M. Kelley (October 24, 1911spaced ndashAugust 5, 1997) was an American politician. He was the second Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1973 to 1978.

[[Floyd I. Clarke]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, American lawyers, Living people, Politicians from Phoenix, Arizona

Floyd I. Clarke (born January 7, 1942) is an American politician and lawyer. He was acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) from July to September in 1993 during the Bill Clinton presidency.

[[Thomas J. Pickard]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Thomas Joseph Pickard (born January 6, 1950) is an American politician. He was an acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 71 days in the summer of 2001 following the resignation of Director Louis Freeh. He left the office a week before the September 11 attacks.

[[Louis Freeh]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Newark, New Jersey, US Republican Party politicians

Louis Joseph Freeh (born January 6, 1950) is an American attorney and former judge. 

He was the fifth Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation from September 1993 to June 2001. He was an Assistant United States Attorney and United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. 

A Republican, he worked for President Bill Clinton. 

[[Erin Babcock]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from uterine cancer, Politicians from Alberta, People from Edmonton

Erin Babcock (June 6, 1981 – April 25, 2020) was a Canadian nurse and politician. She was elected in the 2015 Alberta general election to the Legislative Assembly of Alberta, representing the electoral district of Stony Plain. Her term ended on April 16, 2019. Babcock was a member of the Alberta New Democratic Party.

Babcock was diagnosed with uterine cancer in May 2018. She died from the disease in Edmonton on April 25, 2020 at the age of 38.

[[Enter the Dragon]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 movies, 1970s action movies, American action movies, Hong Kong movies

Enter the Dragon is a 1973 Hong Kong American action movie directed by Robert Clouse and starring Bruce Lee, John Saxon, Jim Kelly, Ahna Capri, Angela Mao, Betty Chung, Bolo Yeung, Marlene Clark. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

It was the last movie Bruce Lee starred in before his death.

[[Burgundy School of Business]]

CATEGORIES: Education in France

Burgundy School of Business is an European higher studies establishment. The school is in 3 places, in Paris, in Lyon and in Dijon. It has been created in 1899. 

BSB is specialist in the fields of economics, social sciences and management.

[[Emperor of the North Pole]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s adventure movies, 1973 drama movies, American adventure movies, Movies directed by Robert Aldrich

Emperor of the North Pole is a 1973 American adventure drama movie directed by Robert Aldrich and stars Lee Marvin, Ernest Borgnine, Keith Carradine, Simon Oakland, Charles Tyner, Harry Caesar. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Soylent Green]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 science fiction movies, 1973 thriller movies, American science fiction movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard Fleischer, Dystopian movies

Soylent Green is a 1973 American science fiction thriller movie directed by Richard Fleischer and loosely based on the 1966 novel Make Room! Make Room!. It stars Charlton Heston, Leigh Taylor-Young, Edward G. Robinson, Joseph Cotten, Brock Peters, Dick Van Patten and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[The Ups and Downs of a Handyman]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 comedy movies, British comedy movies

The Ups and Downs of a Handyman is a 1975 British erotic comedy movie directed by John Sealey and stars Barry Stokes, Sue Lloyd, Gay Soper, Bob Todd, Chic Murray, Harold Bennett. It was distributed by Cannon Films.

[[The Oregon Trail (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies

The Oregon Trail is a 1959 American western movie directed by Gene Fowler Jr. and Fred MacMurray, William Bishop, Nina Shipman, Henry Hull, John Carradine. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Ruth Langsford]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, British game show hosts, English television presenters, Living people

Ruth Langsford (also Holmes; born 17 March 1960) is an English television presenter. She is best known for presenting numerous shows such as This Morning, Gift Wrapped and How the Other Half Lives.

Langsford is also an anchor on ITV's lunchtime chat show Loose Women and presents Ruth Langsford's Fashion Edit on QVC. She took part in the fifteenth series of Strictly Come Dancing, where she came ninth. She was the longest female presenter of This Morning. Ruth was born in Singapore, Southeast Asia.

[[Alaska Passage]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Edward Bernds

Alaska Passage is a 1959 American drama movie directed by Edward Bernds and starring Bill Williams, Naura Hayden, Lyn Thomas, Leslie Bradley, Raymond Hatton. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Compulsion (1959 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950s crime movies, 1959 drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Richard Fleischer

Compulsion is a 1959 American crime drama movie directed by Richard Fleischer and based on the 1956 novel of the same name by Meyer Levin. It stars Orson Welles, Dean Stockwell, Diane Varsi, E. G. Marshall, Bradford Dillman, Martin Milner, Edward Binns and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Last Embrace]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 movies, 1970s mystery movies, 1970s thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Jonathan Demme

Last Embrace is a 1979 American thriller movie directed by Jonathan Demme and based on the novel The 13th Man by Murray Teigh Bloom. It stars Roy Scheider, Janet Margolin, Christopher Walken, Sam Levene, Marcia Rodd, Charles Napier and was distributed by United Artists.

[[You're in the Navy Now]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

You're in the Navy Now is a 1951 American World War II comedy movie directed by Henry Hathaway and starring Gary Cooper, Jane Greer, Millard Mitchell, Eddie Albert, Charles Bronson, Lee Marvin, Ed Begley, Jack Warden, Jack Webb and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Zotz!]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 comedy movies, 1960s fantasy movies, American fantasy-comedy movies, American spy movies, Spy comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by William Castle

Zotz! is a 1962 American fantasy comedy movie directed by William Castle and based on the 1947 novel by Walter Karig. It stars Tom Poston, Julia Meade, Jim Backus, Cecil Kellaway and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Law and the Lawless]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 movies, 1960s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by William F. Claxton

Law of the Lawless is a 1964 American western movie directed by William F. Claxton and stars Dale Robertson, Yvonne De Carlo, John Agar, William Bendix, Lon Chaney Jr., Rod Lauren, Richard Arlen, Bruce Cabot and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Key Exchange]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 romance movies, 1985 comedy movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on plays, 20th Century Fox movies

Key Exchange is a 1985 American romantic comedy movie directed by Barnet Kellman and based on the play of the same name by Kevin Wade. It stars Brooke Adams, Danny Aiello, Ben Masters, Kerry Armstrong, Annie Golden and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Into the Night]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1980s thriller movies, American black comedy movies, Movies directed by John Landis

Into the Night is a 1985 American black comedy thriller movie directed John Landis and stars Jeff Goldblum, Michelle Pfeiffer, Dan Aykroyd, David Bowie, Bruce McGill, Richard Farnsworth, Irene Papps, Clu Gulager, Kathryn Harrold. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Enemy Mine (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 drama movies, 1980s science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, American drama movies, German drama movies, Cult movies, Movies directed by Wolfgang Petersen

Enemy Mine is a 1985 American German science fiction drama movie directed by Wolfgang Petersen and based on the novella of the same name by Barry B. Longyear. It stars Dennis Quaid, Louis Gossett Jr., Brion James, Carolyn McCormick and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was a box office bomb and has since become a cult classic.

[[The Quiet Earth (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 movies, 1980s science fiction movies, New Zealand movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Geoff Murphy, Post-apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

The Quiet Earth is a 1985 New Zealand science fiction movie directed by Geoff Murphy and is loosely based on the 1981 novel of the same name by Craig Harrison. It stars Bruno Lawrence, Alison Routledge, Anzac Wallace.

[[Prizzi's Honor]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1985 drama movies, 1980s crime drama movies, American black comedy movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by John Huston

Prizzi's Honor is a 1985 American black comedy crime drama movie directed by John Huston and based on the 1982 novel of the same name by Richard Condon. It stars Jack Nicholson, Kathleen Turner, Anjelica Huston, Robert Loggia, William Hickey, C. C. H. Pounder, Stanley Tucci, Lawrence Tierney and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 7 Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Actor with Huston winning for Best Supporting Actress in 1986.

[[Almost You]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1985 romance movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies

Almost You is a 1985 American romantic comedy movie directed by Adam Brooks and starring Brooke Adams, Griffin Dunne, Karen Young. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Postman Always Rings Twice (1981 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s erotic movies, 1981 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books

The Postman Always Rings Twice is a 1981 American erotic thriller movie directed by Bob Rafelson and is the fourth adaption of the 1934 novel of the same name by James M. Cain. It stars Jack Nicholson, Jessica Lange, John Colicos, Anjelica Huston, Christopher Lloyd, John P. Ryan and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Psych-Out]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 drama movies, American drama movies, American independent movies

Psych-Out is a 1968 American drama movie directed by Richard Rush and stars Jack Nicholson, Susan Strasberg, Dean Stockwell, Bruce Dern, Max Julien, Strawberry Alarm Clock. It was distributed by American International Pictures.

[[Committee]]

CATEGORIES: government

A committee is a group of people that come together to do something or decide something. It is often part of a bigger deliberative assembly. A committee might have a special job to do for a specific topic.

[[List of United States House of Representatives committees]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States House of Representatives, United States Congress

There are two main types of congressional committees in the United States House of Representatives, standing committees and select committees.

The current House committees were created from the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946. This bill decreased the number of House committees, and it changed the committees' jurisdictions.

[[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States Senate, 1812 establishments in the United States

The United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary, also called the Senate Judiciary Committee, is a standing committee of 22 U.S. Senators whose job is to oversee the Department of Justice (DOJ), question people who have been chosen for executive and  judicial jobs, and review legislation.

It is also in charge of having meetings and investigating people the President chooses to be judges on the Supreme Court, the U.S. court of appeals, the U.S. district courts, and the Court of International Trade.

[[United States Senate Committee on Rules and Administration]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States Senate, 1867 establishments in the United States

The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, also called the Senate Rules Committee, is in charge of the rules of the United States Senate, administration of congressional buildings, monitoring elections and deciding whether or not the members should be there.

[[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States Senate, 1816 establishments in the United States

The United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations is a standing committee of the United States Senate. It is in charge with leading foreign-policy legislation and debate in the Senate. The Foreign Relations Committee is in charge for overseeing (but not administering) and giving money to foreign aid programs as well as buying weapons and training for national allies. The committee is also in charge of questioning people chosen for important jobs in the Department of State. The committee looks at important treaties and legislation, ranging from the Alaska purchase in 1867 to the creation of the United Nations in 1945. It also in charge of people chosen for diplomatic jobs. They deal with U.S. interests with foreign countries.

[[United States House Committee on Financial Services]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States House of Representatives, 1865 establishments in the United States

The United States House Committee on Financial Services, also called the House Banking Committee, is the committee of the United States House of Representatives that oversees the entire financial services industry, including the securities, insurance, banking and housing industries. The Financial Services Committee also oversees the work of the Federal Reserve, the United States Department of the Treasury, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and other financial services regulators.

[[Hebbville, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Hebbville (2006 pop. 780) is an incorporated village bordering the town of Bridgewater in Lunenburg County, Nova Scotia, Canada.

[[Kingston, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Kingston is a Canadian village  in Kings County on the north bank of the Annapolis River in the Annapolis Valley of Nova Scotia, Canada. As of 2016, the population was 3,093.

[[United States House Committee on Oversight and Reform]]

CATEGORIES: Committees of the United States House of Representatives, 1816 establishments in the United States

The Committee on Oversight and Reform is the main investigative committee of the United States House of Representatives.

The committee has broad jurisdiction and strong legislative authority, which makes it one of the most influential and powerful committees in the House. Its chairman is one of only three in the House that can make subpoenas without a committee vote or talking with the ranking member. However, recently, it has become common to not make a subpoena by themselves..

Carolyn Maloney (D-New York) became the acting chair of the committee after Elijah Cummings (D-Maryland) died on October 17, 2019; she was elected chair a month later.

[[Lawrencetown, Annapolis County]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Lawrencetown is a village within Annapolis County in the Annapolis Valley of Nova Scotia, Canada. The town was first settled in 1760 and named after Nova Scotia governor Charles Lawrence. 2016 the population was 516, a decrease of 17.4% over the previous five years.

[[New Minas]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

New Minas is a village located in the eastern part of Kings County in Nova Scotia's Annapolis Valley. As of 2011, the population was 5,135.

[[United States House Oversight Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties]]

CATEGORIES: Subcommittees of the United States House of Representatives

The Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties is a subcommittee within the United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

[[Port Williams, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Port Williams is a Canadian village in Kings County, Nova Scotia. It is located on the north bank of the Cornwallis River, named after Edward Cornwallis, first governor of Nova Scotia.  As of 2016, the population was 1,120.

[[United States House Oversight Subcommittee on Environment]]

CATEGORIES: Subcommittees of the United States House of Representatives

The Subcommittee on Environment is a subcommittee within the U.S. House of Representatives Oversight and Government Reform Committee. 

[[Pugwash, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Pugwash is a village in Cumberland County, Nova Scotia, Canada. It had a population of 736 as of the 2016 census.

[[United States House Financial Services Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Financial Institutions]]

CATEGORIES: Subcommittees of the United States House of Representatives

The U.S. House Financial Services Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Financial Institutions is a subcommittee of the House Committee on Financial Services.

[[United States House Financial Services Subcommittee on Investor Protection, Entrepreneurship and Capital Markets]]

CATEGORIES: Subcommittees of the United States House of Representatives

The U.S. House Financial Services Subcommittee on Investor Protection, Entrepreneurship and Capital Markets is a subcommittee of the House Committee on Financial Services.

[[River Hebert, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

River Hebert is a village on the River Hebert in Cumberland County, Nova Scotia, Canada.It is approximately 25 kilometres southwest of Amherst. As of 2006 the population was 543.

[[Hammerwich]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Staffordshire, Civil parishes in Staffordshire

Hammerwich is a small village and civil parish in Lichfield District, Staffordshire, England. It is south-east of Burntwood. About 700 people lived there in 2011.

[[St. Peter's, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

St. Peter's (Scottish Gaelic: Baile Pheadair; formerly known as "Santo Pedro", "Saint-Pierre", "Port Toulouse", and "St. Peters") is a small incorporated village  located on Cape Breton Island in Richmond County, Nova Scotia, Canada.

[[PEN Oakland awards]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 establishments in California, Awards

The PEN Oakland/Josephine Miles Literary Award is for U.S. multicultural writers. It is to "promote works by writers of all cultural and racial backgrounds and to educate both the public and the media as to the nature of multicultural work." It was created by PEN Oakland in 1991. It was named in honor of Josephine Miles. PEN Oakland was created in 1989. The award was called the "Blue Collar PEN Award" by The New York Times.

[[Tatamagouche]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Tatamagouche ˌ (Mi'kmaq: Taqamiju’jk) is a village in Colchester County, Nova Scotia, Canada.

[[Tiverton, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Tiverton is a small village located on the northeast tip of Long Island, Nova Scotia. Tiverton has a population of about 300 people. It was named for Tiverton, Devon. 

The main industry is lobster fishing, while a second, and growing industry, is tourism. The Bay of Fundy is known for whale watching, and Tiverton and the surrounding area offer several tours operating throughout the summer months. Another attraction is Balancing Rock, a large basalt column that appears to be balancing on its end on the southern shore just outside Tiverton.

[[Ernesto Nieto]]

CATEGORIES: People from Houston, Texas, Living people, 1940 births

Ernesto Nieto (born October 6, 1940) is the creator of the National Hispanic Institute. He has served as President since the organization's creation in 1979.

[[Westport, Nova Scotia]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nova Scotia

Westport, Nova Scotia is a village in Digby County, Nova Scotia and it is located on Brier Island in the Bay of Fundy. As of 2016, the population was 218.

[[Kanifing (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia

Kanifing is one of eight Local Government Areas in The Gambia. The municipality has the most people of any of the administrative districts in Gambia. It is immediately west of the City of Banjul. It includes Serrekunda, the largest urban area in the Gambia.

[[Spike protein]]

CATEGORIES: Viruses

A Spike protein or peplomer is a glycoprotein spike on the outside layer (or capsid) of a virus. When a virus attaches to a cell, these peplomers can only attach to certain receptors on the cell. They are very important for choosing which cell it attaches to and how infectious a virus is.

[[Brikama (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia

Brikama is one of eight Local Government Areas in the Gambia. The headquarters of the Brikama LGA are at Brikama town. About 700,000 people lived there in 2013.

[[Mansa Konko]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Gambia, Local Government Areas of the Gambia

Mansa Konko is a town and Local Government Area in The Gambia. It is the capital city of the Lower River Region.

[[Kerewan (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Gambia, Local Government Areas of the Gambia

Kerewan is one of eight Local Government Areas (LGA) in the Gambia. It is north of the Gambia River. 

The city of Kerewan is the headquarters of the North Bank Region. In 2013 about 220,000 lived in the LGA. Of those, about 200,000 lived in the city.

[[Kuntaur (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia, Cities in the Gambia

Kuntaur is one of eight Local Government Areas in the Gambia.

The town of Kuntaur is the last inland port for large ships. It had about 3,000 people living there in 2013.

[[Michael Robinson (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Spain, Deaths from melanoma, English footballers, Spanish footballers, English television presenters, Irish television presenters, Irish footballers, English sports commentators, Liverpool F.C. players, Sportspeople from Leicester

Michael John Robinson (12 July 1958 – 27 April 2020) was an English-born professional footballer and sports commentator. He played as a striker.

Robinson was born in Leicester. He played in more than 300 official matches in England for five clubs, including Liverpool. He also played the last three seasons of his career in Spain with Osasuna. He represented the Republic of Ireland at international level.

Robinson retired in 1989. He became a Spanish citizen. He was also a television presenter. In December 2018, Robinson announced he had melanoma. He died in Marbella on 27 April 2020 at the age of 61.

[[Janjanbureh (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia, Cities in the Gambia

Janjanbureh is one of eight Local Government Areas in the Gambia. 

The town of Janjanbureh is on MacCarthy Island in the Gambia River. It used to be named Georgetown.

[[Ozren Grabarić]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, Croatian actors, People from Zagreb

Ozren Grabarić (born 17 July 1980) is a Croatian actor, member of the Gavella Theatre in Zagreb, often featured in TV series and in film. He is a professor at the Academy of Dramatic Art in Zagreb. He voiced Crane in the Croatian dub of the Kung Fu Panda films.

[[Basse (Gambia)]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia

Basse is one of eight Local Government Areas in the Gambia. About 240,000 people lived there in 2013. It has a land area of 2,069.5 square kilometres.

[[Palatine bone]]

The palatine bone is a paired bone which forms part of the nasal cavity and hard palate. It is located between the maxilla and sphenoid bone. In simple terms it is locates on both sides of nose.

[[Local Government Areas of the Gambia]]

CATEGORIES: Local Government Areas of the Gambia

The Gambia is divided into eight local government areas. These are divided into 43 districts. 

[[Secondary color]]

CATEGORIES: Color

Secondary colors are colors made from two primary colors. In RYB, the secondary colors are orange, mixed from red and yellow, green, mixed from yellow and blue, and purple, mixed from red and blue. In RGB, the secondary colors are yellow, mixed from red and lime, cyan, mixed with lime and blue, and magenta, mixed from red and blue. The secondary colors from RYB are known as OGP, and from RGB, it is CMYK.

When mixed with primary colors, it makes a teritary color.

[[Tertiary color]]

CATEGORIES: Color

Teritary colors are colors mixed from primary colors, and secondary colors.

[[RGB]]

CATEGORIES: Color

RGB, also called additive color mixing, is a color coding using light, with red, green, and blue. It is used in a hexadecimal code (#RRGGBB), with the left two digits with red, the center with green, and the right with blue. There can only be a maximum 255 of each color.

[[Police impersonation]]

CATEGORIES: Crime

Police impersonation is when someone pretends to be a police officer. It is illegal in most countries.

[[Prime Minister of Serbia]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Serbia

The Prime Minister of Serbia (Serbian: Премијер Србије / Premijer Srbije), officially the President of the Government of the Republic of Serbia (Председник Владе Републике Србије / Predsednik Vlade Republike Srbije), is the Head of government of Serbia. The prime minister works for the Government, and sends it to the National Assembly the Government's Program.

The current Prime Minister, Ana Brnabić was nominated by the former Prime Minister and newly elected President of the Republic, Aleksandar Vučić and elected and appointed by the National Assembly on 29 June 2017. 

[[Dragutin Zelenović]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Educators, Prime Ministers of Serbia

Dragutin Zelenović (Драгутин Зеленовић; 19 May 1928 — 27 April 2020) was a Serbian educator and politician. He was rector of the University of Novi Sad. He was a member of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts. He was the Prime Minister of Serbia in 1991. 

He was a professor at the Faculty of Technical Sciences and Rector of the University of Novi Sad (1987–89). 

He died on 27 April 2020 in Novi Sad, aged 91.

[[Tanjung Pinang]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Indonesia

Tanjung Pinang is the capital city of the Indonesian province of the Riau Islands. It covers a land area of 144.56 km2. With an estimated population of 209,280 as of 2018, it is the second largest city of the province, after Batam. Tanjung Pinang is a historic city of the Malay culture, serving as the capital of Johor Sultanate and Riau-Lingga Sultanate.

[[Syahrul]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia, Indonesian politicians, Indonesian educators, Mayors

Syahrul (August 30, 1960 – April 28, 2020) was an Indonesian politician, teacher, and member of the Great Indonesia Movement Party. He was the Mayor of Tanjung Pinang, and capital and second largest city in the Riau Islands, from September 21, 2018, until his death on April 28, 2020. He was Deputy Mayor of Tanjung Pinang from 2013 to 2018.

Syahrul died in April 2020 from COVID-19, aged 59.

[[Alexander Münninghoff]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Chess players, Dutch journalists, Dutch sportspeople, People from Poznań

Alexander Münninghoff (13 April 1944 – 28 April 2020) was a Polish-born Dutch journalist and chess player. From 1974 to 2007, he worked for the Haagsche Courant. Münninghoff wrote among others many articles and books about chess sport. He was born in Poznan, Poland. In 1983 he won the Prijs voor de Dagbladjournalistiek and in 2015 he won the Libris Geschiedenis Prijs for his book De stamhouder.

Münninghoff died at his home in The Hague on 28 April 2020, aged 76.refhttps://www.denhaagcentraal.net/nieuws/alexander-munninghoff-76-overleden/

[[Harland Svare]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American football linebackers, New York Giants players, Los Angeles Rams players, Deaths from respiratory arrest, Sportspeople from Minnesota

Harland James Svare (November 25, 1930 – April 4, 2020) was a American professional football player and coach.  Svare was a linebacker who played eight seasons with the Los Angeles Rams and New York Giants of the National Football League (NFL) from 1953 to 1960.  He was the Rams head coach from the 1962 season through 1965 and the San Diego Chargers head coach from 1971 through 1973. He was born in Clarkfield, Minnesota.

Svare died on April 4, 2020 of respiratory arrest in Steamboat Springs, Colorado at the age of 89.

[[Clarkfield, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

Clarkfield is a city in Yellow Medicine County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 863 at the 2010 census.

[[Granite Falls, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota, County seats in Minnesota

Granite Falls is a city in Chippewa and Yellow Medicine counties in the State of Minnesota. The population was 2,897 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Yellow Medicine County.

[[Ronnie Earle]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Fort Worth, Texas, Politicians from Austin, Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

Ronald Dale Earle (February 23, 1942 – April 5, 2020) was an American Democratic politician and lawyer. He was born in Fort Worth, Texas. From 1977 to 2009, he was the District Attorney of Travis County, Texas. He was known for being the judge that prosecuted House Majority Leader Tom DeLay for money laundering.

Earle died on April 5, 2020 in Austin, Texas after a long-illness, aged 78.

[[Albert H. Wilkening]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American generals, People from New York, People from Wisconsin

Major General Albert H. Wilkening (February 1, 1946 – April 8, 2020) was an American major general. He was an adjutant general of Wisconsin from 2002 to 2007. He was responsible for both the federal and state missions of the Wisconsin Army and Air National Guard and the Wisconsin Division of Emergency Management. 

In March 2003, Wilkening was appointed by Governor Jim Doyle as in charge of the Homeland Security Council in Wisconsin and to be the governor's homeland security advisor. He was born in Freeport, New York.

Wilkening died of pancreatic cancer in Wisconsin on April 8, 2020, at the age of 74.

[[Freeport, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Freeport (officially The Incorporated Village of Freeport) is a village in the town of Hempstead, Nassau County, New York, US, on the South Shore of Long Island. The population was 43,713 at the 2010 census. 

[[Jim Doyle]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, American educators, Living people, American lawyers, Governors of Wisconsin, Politicians from Washington, D.C., US Democratic Party politicians

James Edward Doyle, Jr., (born November 23, 1945) is an American lawyer and politician. He is a member of the Democratic Party. He was the 44th Governor of Wisconsin from January 6, 2003 to January 3, 2011.

[[Marianne Lundquist]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Sweden, Swedish Olympians, Sportspeople from Stockholm

Ingrid Marianne Lundquist (later Grane, 24 July 1931 – 10 April 2020) was a Swedish freestyle swimmer. She was born in Stockholm. Lundquist won a bronze medal in the 4 × 100 m relay at the  1950 European Aquatics Championships. She competed at the 1948 and 1952 Olympics. 

Lundquist died on 10 April 2020 from COVID-19 in Stockholm, aged 88.

[[Lowell A. Reed Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

Lowell A. Reed Jr. (June 21, 1930 – April 11, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania from 1988 to 1999. He was nominated by President Ronald Reagan. Reed Jr. was born in West Chester, Pennsylvania.

Reed Jr. died on April 11, 2020 in Jenkintown, Pennsylvania of Parkinson's disease-related problems, aged 89.

[[Jenkintown, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Jenkintown is a borough in Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, about 10 miles (16 km) north of Philadelphia.

[[Axel Berg (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian footballers

Axel August Berg (8 July 1938 – 12 April 2020) was a Norwegian football winger. He played for Lyn between 1955 and 1965 and the national team from 1959 and 1961. 

Berg died on 12 April 2020, aged 81.

[[Elisabeth Berge]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian politicians, Norwegian businesspeople

Elisabeth Berge (27 November 1954 – 13 April 2020) was a Norwegian businessperson and politician. She worked in the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy from 1981 to 1990. She then worked in Statoil from 1990 to 2004. Beginning in 2001, she was chief of communications. In 2004 she was appointed permanent under-secretary of State in the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy.

Berge died on 13 April 2020, aged 65.

[[Paul Ronty]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Bruins players, Canadian ice hockey centres, Ice hockey people from Ontario, Montreal Canadiens players, New York Rangers players, Sportspeople from Toronto

Paul Ronty (July 12, 1928 – April 22, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey centre. Ronty started his National Hockey League career with the Boston Bruins in 1947.  He also played for the New York Rangers and Montreal Canadiens. He retired after the 1955 season. He was born in Toronto.

Ronty died on April 22, 2020 in Newton, Massachusetts at the age of 91.

[[Brian Stepanek]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Cleveland, Ohio, American stage actors

Brian Patrick Stepanek (born February 6, 1971) is an American actor. He was born in Cleveland, Ohio. He is known for his role as Arwin Hawkhauser on the Disney Channel Original Series The Suite Life of Zack & Cody and Brian on Brian O'Brian. He was also a Sector Seven Agent in the 2007 Michael Bay movie Transformers. He played Tom Harper on the Nickelodeon series Nicky, Ricky, Dicky & Dawn from 2014 to 2018.

[[Lynn Harrell]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Musicians from New York City

Lynn Harrell (January 30, 1944 – April 27, 2020) was an American classical cellist. He was born in New York City. Harrell made his recital debut in New York in 1971. He was the Music Director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Institute from 1988 to 1992. From 1986 to 1993, he held the post of "Gregor Piatigorsky Endowed Chair in Violoncello" at the University of Southern California. 

Harrell died on April 27, 2020 in Santa Monica, California of cardiac arrest at the age of 76.

[[Francesco Perrone]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Italian Olympians

Francesco Perrone (3 December 1930 – 27 April 2020) was an Italian long-distance runner. He competed in the marathon at the 1960 Summer Olympics. Perrone was an athlete of the Gruppo Sportivo Fiamme Oro. He was born in Cellino San Marco, Italy.

Perrone died of COVID-19 on 27 April 2020 in Bari, Italy at the age of 89.

[[Mohammad Shariff (admiral)]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Pakistani people, Military people

Admiral Mohammad Shariff (Urdu: ايڈمرل محمد شريف ; born 1920 – 27 April 2020NI(M), HI(M), SI(M), LM, HJ, SJ, SK), was a four-star rank admiral. He was an important figure in the Indo-Pakistani war of 1971. He was the Chief of Naval Staff from 1975 to 1979 and Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee from 1977 to 1980.

Shariff died on 27 April 2020, aged 99.

[[Kim Rhodes]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Portland, Oregon, Singers from Portland, Oregon

Kimberly Rhodes (born June 7, 1969) is an American actress. She is known for her roles as Ensign Lydnsey Ballard in "Ashes to Ashes" episode of Star Trek Voyager, Cindy Harrison on two different soap operas, Another World and As the World Turns, and as Carey Martin in the Disney Channel sitcom The Suite Life of Zack & Cody and The Suite Life on Deck, She is also known for playing Sheriff Jody Mills on Supernatural.

[[Nur Yerlitaş]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Fashion designers, People from Istanbul

Nuray "Nur" Yerlitaş (11 August 1955 – 27 April 2020) was a Turkish fashion designer. She was born in Istanbul. She was a judge on the television reality show İşte Benim Stilim from 2015 to 2017. She started her career by selling accessories from Italy. In the following years she opened her own boutique and entered into designing business.

In August 2018, Yerlitaş was diagnosed with brain cancer. She died on 27 April 2020 at her home in Istanbul from the disease, aged 64.

[[Giacomo dalla Torre del Tempio di Sanguinetto]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from throat cancer, Princes and Grand Masters of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, People from Rome

Fra' Giacomo dalla Torre del Tempio di Sanguinetto (9 December 1944 – 29 April 2020) was an Italian nobility. He was the 80th Prince and Grand Master of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta in 2008 and again from 2017 until his death. 

His full title is His Most Eminent Highness Fra' Giacomo dalla Torre del Tempio di Sanguinetto, Prince and Grand Master of the Sovereign Military Hospitaller Order of St. John of Jerusalem, of Rhodes and of Malta, Most Humble Guardian of the Poor of Jesus Christ. He was born in Rome. 

Dalla Torre died on 29 April 2020 in Rome from throat cancer, aged 75.

[[List of Grand Masters of the Knights Hospitaller]]

CATEGORIES: Princes and Grand Masters of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta

This is a list of  Grand Masters of the Knights Hospitaller including their replacement Sovereign Military Order of Malta after 1798.

[[Adjara]]

CATEGORIES: Autonomous republics of Georgia (country), 1991 establishments in Europe

Adjara is a region of Georgia. Its official name is Autonomous Republic of Adjara. The capital city is Batumi, which is the 2nd largest city in Georgia.

The region is on the coast of the Black Sea near the foot of the Lesser Caucasus Mountains. About 333,953 people live there (2014).

There are 5 municipalities plus the city of Batumi. The five municipalities are:

[[Ludwig Hoffmann-Rumerstein]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Princes and Grand Masters of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, Austrian people

Fra' Ludwig Hoffmann von Rumerstein (born January 21, 1937) is an Austrian nobility. He was the interim Prince and Grand Master of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta in 2017. From 1994 to 2004 and again from 2014 to 2019, he was Grand Commander of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. He was born in Innsbruck.

[[Ron Marlenee]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, United States representatives from Montana, People from Bozeman, Montana, US Republican Party politicians

Ronald Charles "Ron" Marlenee (August 8, 1935 – April 26, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was  in the United States House of Representatives from Montana between January 3, 1977 to January 3, 1993. He represented MT. Marlenee was born in Scobey, Montana.

Marlenee died on April 26, 2020 in Bozeman, Montana of a short-illness, aged 84.

[[South Berwick, Maine]]

South Berwick is a town in York County, Maine, United States. The population was 7,220 at the 2010 census.

[[York County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 1630s establishments in the Thirteen Colonies, 1636 establishments, Maine counties

York County is the southwesternmost county in the U.S. state of Maine. As of the 2010 census, the population was 197,131. Its county seat is Alfred.

[[Alfred, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine, County seats in Maine

Alfred is a town in York County, Maine, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town population was 3,019. Alfred is the seat of York County.

[[Guria]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Georgia (country)

Guria is a region in Georgia. The capital city is Ozurgeti. It is bordered by the eastern end of the Black Sea.

[[Auburn, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maine, County seats in Maine

Auburn is a small city in south-central Maine, United States. The city is the county seat of Androscoggin County. The population was 23,055 at the 2010 census. Auburn and its sister city Lewiston are known locally as the Twin Cities or Lewiston–Auburn (L–A).

[[Ellsworth, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maine, County seats in Maine

Ellsworth is a city in and the county seat of Hancock County, Maine, United States. The 2010 Census it had a population of 7,741.

[[Rockland, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maine, County seats in Maine

Rockland is a city in Knox County, Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 7,297. It is the county seat of Knox County. 

[[Wiscasset, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine, County seats in Maine

Wiscasset is a town in and the seat of Lincoln County, Maine, United States. The population was 3,732 as of the 2010 census. 

[[Penobscot County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Maine, 1816 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Penobscot County is a county in the U.S. state of Maine. As of the 2010 census, the population was 153,923. Its county seat is Bangor. Penobscot County is home to the University of Maine.

[[Piscataquis County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Maine counties

Piscataquis County is a county located in the U.S. state of Maine. As of the 2010 census, its population was 17,535, making it Maine's least-populous county. Its county seat is Dover-Foxcroft.

[[Sagadahoc County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Maine, 1854 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Sagadahoc County (ˈ SAG) is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the county's population was 35,293. The county seat is Bath.

[[Paris, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine, County seats in Maine

Paris is a town in and the county seat of Oxford County, Maine, United States. The population was 5,183 at the 2010 census.

[[Oxford County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Maine, 1805 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Oxford County is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 Census, the county had a population of 57,833. Its county seat is the town of Paris.

[[Belfast, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maine, County seats in Maine

Belfast is a city in Waldo County, Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 6,668.

Waldo County is a county in the state of Maine, in the United States. As of the 2010 census, the county's population was 38,786. The county seat is Belfast.
