Kiss Me Deadly is a 1955 crime thriller movie directed by Robert Aldrich and based on the novel of the same name by Mickey Spillane. It stars Ralph Meeker, Albert Dekker, Paul Stewart, Juano Hernandez, Wesley Addy, Maxine Cooper, Cloris Leachman, Leigh Snowden and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Jericho Brown]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, African American writers, American poets, Gay men, Living people, LGBT African Americans, LGBT people from Louisiana, LGBT poets, People from Shreveport, Louisiana, Pulitzer Prize winners, Writers from Louisiana

Jericho Brown (born Nelson Demery III; born April 14, 1976) is an American poet. In 2020, he was awarded a Pulitzer Prize  for Poetry.

[[Gremlins]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 horror movies, 1984 comedy movies, American horror movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Joe Dante

Gremlins is a 1984 American comedy horror movie written by Chris Columbus and directed by Joe Dante. 

The movie is about a kid who receives a strange creature called a mogwai as a pet, which then turns other creatures who transform into small, destructive, evil monsters. The movie stars Zach Galligan and Phoebe Cates, with Howie Mandel. Steven Spielberg was the movie's executive producer.

It was followed by a sequel, Gremlins 2: The New Batch, in 1990. 

Despite being a critical and commercial success, the movie had mixed reviews. This movie is one of the reasons why the PG-13 rating was created because it was made as a family movie, but had some violence and bloody scenes.

[[Harry Carey]]

CATEGORIES: 1878 births, 1947 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Deaths from coronary thrombosis, American silent movie actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, Actors from New York City

Henry DeWitt Carey II (January 16, 1878 – September 21, 1947) was an American actor. He was a well known silent movie actor who was seen many times as a Western hero. 

One of his best known roles was as the President of the Senate (Vice President of the United States) in the drama movie Mr. Smith Goes to Washington (1939). He was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. 

He was the father of Harry Carey Jr., who was also an actor. In 1920, he married actress Olive Fuller Golden.

Carey was born in The Bronx. He died of lung cancer and coronary thrombosis caused by a spider bite on September 21, 1947 in Los Angeles, aged 69.

[[Lure of the Swamp]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, American drama movies

Lure of the Swamp is a 1957 American drama movie directed by Hubert Cornfield and starring Willard Parker, Marshall Thompson, Joan Vohs, Jack Elam, Leo Gordon. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Matt Clark]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, American movie actors, American television actors, American television directors, American stage actors, American television producers, American movie directors, Living people, Actors from Washington, D.C.

Matthew Clark (born November 25, 1936) is an American actor and director. Clark has played many character roles in Westerns, comedies, and dramas. He was born in Washington, D.C.. His best known role is as Chester the Bartender in the 1990 movie Back to the Future Part III. He also played Uncle Henry in Return to Oz (1985). 

[[Don Shula]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Cleveland Browns players, Indianapolis Colts players, Washington Redskins players, American football coaches, American football defensive tackles, Businesspeople from Ohio, Sportspeople from Ohio, Businesspeople from Miami, Florida, Sportspeople from Miami, Florida

Donald Francis Shula (January 4, 1930 – May 4, 2020) was an American professional football coach and player. He had the most wins for a coach in National Football League (NFL) history.

Shula was best known for his time being the longtime head coach of the Miami Dolphins, leading them to two Super Bowl victories. He was the head coach of the Baltimore Colts. He played professionally as a defensive back for the Cleveland Browns, Baltimore Colts, and Washington Redskins.

In 1997, he was added to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. In retirement, he owned many steak restaurants and a line of condiments.

Shula was born in Grand River, Ohio. He studied at John Carroll University. Shula died on May 4, 2020 in Indian Creek, Florida at the age of 90.

[[Grand River, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Ohio

Grand River is a village in Lake County, Ohio, United States, along the Grand River. The population was 399 at the 2010 census.

[[Indian Creek, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Florida

Indian Creek is a wealthy village in Miami-Dade County, Florida, United States. The population was 86 at the 2010 census. It was the 5th highest-income place in Florida. It is near Miami.

[[Frankenstein Must Be Destroyed]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 movies, 1960s horror movies, British horror movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Terence Fisher

Frankenstein Must Be Destroyed is a 1969 British Hammer horror movie directed by Terence Fisher. It is the fifth movie in the Hammer's Frankenstein series and stars Peter Cushing, Veronica Carlson, Simon Ward, Peter Copley, Windsor Davies, Thorley Walters, Frank Middlemass, Freddie Jones. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[John Carroll University]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Ohio

John Carroll University is a private Jesuit university in University Heights, Ohio. It is an undergraduate, liberal arts institution. John Carroll has an enrollment of 3,650 students. 

The university has undergraduate programs in the liberal arts, sciences, and business, and in selected areas at the master's level. The university has been ranked in the top 10 of Midwest regional universities by U.S. News & World Report's annual guide, "America's Best Colleges," for 29 years in a row.

[[University Heights, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

University Heights is a city in Cuyahoga County, Ohio,  United States. The population was 13,539 as of the 2010 Census. University Heights is nicknamed the "City of Beautiful Homes."  

[[Froilan Tenorio]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, United States representatives, Governors of the Northern Mariana Islands, Living people, US Democratic Party politicians

Froilan Cruz Tenorio (September 9, 1939 – May 4, 2020) was a Northern Mariana Islands politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party. From 1984 to 1990, he was a Resident U.S. Representative. He was the 4th Governor of Northern Mariana Islands from 1994 to 1998.

Tenorio died on May 4, 2020 in Fort Worth, Texas at the age of 80.

[[Tom Lupo]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine scientists, Argentine journalists, Radio personalities, Poets

Tom Lupo (born Carlos Luis Galanternik; 22 October 1945 – 4 May 2020) was an Argentine poet, psychoanalyst and radio personality. He was born in Charata, Argentina. He hosted the radio show The Tom Lupo Show. In 2011, he released a poetry collection titled Giro hondo. He hosted many shows on Televisión Pública.

Lupo died on 4 May 2020 in Buenos Aires, aged 74.

[[Let's Make Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 comedy movies, 1960s musical movies, 1960s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by George Cukor

Let's Make Love is a 1960 American romantic musical comedy movie directed by George Cukor and starring Marilyn Monroe, Yves Montand, Tony Randall, Gene Kelly, Bing Crosby, Frankie Vaughan. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for Academy Award in 1961.

[[MatPat]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American YouTubers, American television presenters, Writers from Ohio, Entertainers from Ohio

Matthew Robert Patrick (born November 15, 1986), also known by his screen name MatPat, is an American internet personality. He is the creator and narrator of the YouTube webseries The Game Theorists. He often talks about the logical, statistics, data and breakdown of movie scenes, game shows, or theories. He was born in Medina, Ohio.

Between July 1, 2016, and July 31, 2016, he starred in the game show The Runner.

In 2012, he married Stephanie Cordato. They have one son.

[[Ömer Döngeloğlu]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Television presenters, Theologians, Researchers, Turkish writers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Turkey

Ömer Döngeloğlu (1968 – 3 May 2020) was a Turkish theologian, writer, producer and television presenter. He was known for the religious programs he hosted on Kanal 7. He was born in Zile, Turkey.

He worked as a preacher in his hometown in Tokat between 1986 to 1996. He worked in many administrative positions in the public sector for many years. He spent years researching, studying and reading Islamic history and Siyer-i Nebi.

Döngeloğlu died from COVID-19 in Istanbul on 3 May 2020, aged 52.

[[Yusuf Kenan Sönmez]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Turkey, Turkish politicians, Turkish businesspeople

Yusuf Kenan Sönmez (1948 – 3 April 2020) was a Turkish politician and businessman. He was born in Zonguldak, Turkey. He represented Istanbul in the Grand National Assembly from 1987 to 1991. He was a member of both Social Democratic Populist Party and Republican People's Party.

On 25 March 2020, he was diagnosed with COVID-19. On 3 April 2020, he died due to problems from the infection in Istanbul.

[[Journey to the Center of the Earth (1959 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 movies, 1950s adventure movies, 1950s science fiction movies, American adventure movies, American science fiction movies, Movies directed by Henry Levin

Journey to the Center of the Earth is a 1959 American science fiction family adventure movie directed by Henry Levin and is based on the 1864 novel of the same name by Jules Verne. It stars James Mason, Pat Boone, Arlene Dahl, Thayer David and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 1960.

[[Aytaç Yalman]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Turkish military people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Turkey, Generals

Aytaç Yalman (29 July 1940 – 15 March 2020) was a Turkish general. He was born in Istanbul. From 2000 to 2002, he was General Commander of the Gendarmerie of Turkey. From 2002 to 2004, he was the Commander of the Turkish Army. 

Yalman died on 15 March 2020 in Üsküdar, Turkey of COVID-19, aged 79.

[[Belly (rapper)]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian rap musicians, Canadian singers, Canadian songwriters, Hip hop musicians, Living people, Record producers, Trap musicians, 1984 births

Belly (born Ahmad Kasem Balshe on 7 April 1984) is a Canadian rapper, hip hop singer, songwriter, and record producer. He first appeared on Massari's third single "Rush the Floor" and his first solo single "Pressure" premiered in January 2007. His second single "Don't Be Shy" features Ninja Sky and premiered in April 2007. Belly's debut album is called The Revlution.

[[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Turkey

The Grand National Assembly of Turkey, usually known as the TBMM or Parliament is the unicameral Turkish legislature. It is the only body of government in the country as said in the Turkish Constitution. 

It was founded in Ankara on 23 April 1920 in the midst of the National Campaign. 

The current Speaker of the Grand National Assembly is Mustafa Şentop since 2019.

[[Yojimbo]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 drama movies, 1960s action movies, Japanese movies, Movies directed by Akira Kurosawa

Yojimbo is a 1961 Japanese action drama movie directed by Akira Kurosawa and is followed up by the 1962 movie Sanjuro. It stars Toshiro Mifune, Tatsuya Nakadai, Yoko Tsukasa, Isuzu Yamada, Daisuke Katō and was distributed by Toho. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1962.

[[Speaker of the Grand National Assembly]]

CATEGORIES: Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

This article lists the speakers of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey. The name of the parliament of the Republic of Turkey, originally and currently the Grand National Assembly of Turkey.

[[Mustafa Şentop]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1968 births, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

Mustafa Şentop (born on 6 August 1968) is a Turkish politician. He was a member of the Justice and Development Party (AK Party). He was the Member of Parliament for İstanbul in the Turkish Parliament since 2011. 

On 24 February 2019, he was elected as the 29th Speaker of the Grand National Assembly.

[[Fuat Oktay]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1964 births, Turkish politicians, Vice presidents

Fuat Oktay (born 1964) is a Turkish politician, civil servant and academic. He is the first and current Vice President of Turkey since 2018.

[[DaHeala]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian songwriters, Living people, Record producers

Jason "DaHeala" Quenneville is a Canadian record producer, songwriter, and engineer. He is best known for his collaborations with The Weeknd. Quenneville co-wrote and co-produced his albums Kiss Land (2013) and Beauty Behind the Madness (2015). In 2016, he was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Song at the 88th Academy Awards for co-writing his song "Earned It" from Fifty Shades of Grey; the nomination is shared with The Weeknd, Belly, and Stephen Moccio.

[[İsmail Kahraman]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

İsmail Kahraman (born 1940) is a Turkish politician. He is a member of the Justice and Development Party (AKP). He was the 27th Speaker of the Grand National Assembly from 22 November 2015 to 7 July 2018. He has been the Member of Parliament for İstanbul's first electoral district since 1 November 2015.

[[Ömer İzgi]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1940 births, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

Ömer İzgi (born 1 January 1940) is a former Turkish politician and lawyer. He was the Speaker of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey from 2000 to 2002. He was a Member of Parliament for the electoral district of Konya between 1999 and 2002 from the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP).

[[Three Murderesses]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 comedy movies, French comedy movies, Italian comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies

Three Murderesses (Faibles femmes, Le donne sono deboli) also known as Women Are Weak is a 1959 French Italian comedy movie directed by Michel Boisrond and starring Alain Delon, Pascale Petit, Mylène Demongeot, Pierre Mondy, Jacqueline Sassard. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Hikmet Çetin]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

Hikmet Çetin (born 1937) is a Turkish politician. He was the Speaker of the Turkish Grand National Assembly from 1997 to 1999.

[[İsmet Sezgin]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

İsmet Sezgin (6 January 1928 – 7 December 2016) was a Turkish politician. 

He was the Deputy Prime Minister of Turkey and Minister of National Defense from 1997 to 1999, as the Speaker of the Grand National Assembly in 1995, as the Minister of the Interior from 1991 to 1993, as the Minister of Finance from 1979 to 1980 and as the Minister of Youth and Sports from 1969 to 1971. 

Between 1999 and 2002, he was the Leader of the Democrat Turkey Party, but did not contest any elections.

Sezgin died of multiple organ failure on 7 December 2016 in Ankara, aged 88.

[[Doc McKinney]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian songwriters, Living people, Record producers, 1971 births

Martin "Doc" McKinney (born 27 August 1971) is a Canadian-born U.S-raised record producer and songwriter.  He is a Grammy-award-winning producer.  He is professionally referred to as "Doc McKinney". McKinney was formerly one half of the of the formed duet Esthero, alongside Jenny-Bea Englishman. McKinney is now a solo artist. McKinney also owned and operated Black Corners Ent, a joint venture through Sony/Columbia Records in the United States.

[[Hüsamettin Cindoruk]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Presidents of Turkey, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

Ahmet Hüsamettin Cindoruk (born 1933) is a Turkish politician. He was the 17th Speaker of the Parliament of Turkey between 1991 to 1995. He was also the Acting President of Turkey in 1993 following the death of Turgut Özal.

[[Kaya Erdem]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Speakers of the Parliament of Turkey

İsmet Kaya Erdem (born 1928) is a Turkish politician. He was the Minister of Finance from 1980 to 1982. He also was the Speaker of the Grand National Assembly from 1989 to 1991. Erdem was born in Karabük, Turkey. He was a member of the Motherland Party.

[[J. D.'s Revenge]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s action movies, 1976 horror movies, American action movies, American horror movies

J. D.'s Revenge is a 1976 American action horror movie directed by Arthur Marks and starring Glynn Turman, Louis Gossett Jr., Nigel Davenport, Joan Pringle, Julian Christopher, Earl Billings. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Gruschwitz Textilwerke]]

CATEGORIES: 1810s establishments in Germany, 1816 establishments in Europe, Companies of Germany, Baden-Württemberg, Textile industry

Gruschwitz Textilwerke AG is a textile industry company based in Leutkirch im Allgäu in Baden-Württemberg in Germany.

[[Evan Taubenfeld]]

CATEGORIES: American pop musicians, American producers, American singer-songwriters, Living people, 1983 births

Evan David Taubenfeld (born 27 June 1983) is an American musician, singer-songwriter, producer, executive music director, and actor. He was Avril Lavigne's lead guitarist from spring 2002 to September 2004.

[[The Sunday Woman (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 movies, 1970s thriller movies, Italian thriller movies, Movies directed by Luigi Comencini

The Sunday Woman (La donna della domenica) is a 1975 Italian thriller movie directed by Luigi Comencini and based on the novel of the same name. It stars Marcello Mastroianni, Jacqueline Bisset, Jean-Louis Trintignant and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Dave Greenfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, English rock singers, Keyboardists, English rock musicians, Entertainers from Brighton, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, English singer-songwriters

David Paul Greenfield (29 March 1949 – 3 May 2020) was an English keyboardist and singer-songwriter. He was a member of rock band The Stranglers.  He joined the band in 1975, and played with them for 45 years until his death. He was born in Brighton, East Sussex.

Greenfield died on 3 May 2020 of heart failure caused by COVID-19, aged 71.

[[Jackson County Jail]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 crime movies, 1970s thriller movies, American thriller movies

Jackson County Jail is a 1976 American crime thriller movie directed by Michael Miller and starring Tommy Lee Jones, Yvette Mimieux, Robert Carradine, Britt Leach. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Jax Jones]]

CATEGORIES: British DJs, British record producers, English songwriters, Living people, Musicians from London, 1987 births

Timucin Fabian Kwong Wah Aulo (born 25 July 1987), known professionally as Jax Jones, is an English DJ, record producer, remixer, and songwriter. He rose to fame in 2014 by featuring on Duke Dumont's UK number one single "I Got U". He followed this up with "You Don't Know Me" featuring Raye, and "Instruction" featuring Demi Lovato and Stefflon Don in 2016 and 2017, respectively. He formed the alias Europa with fellow DJ Martin Solevig in 2019. 

Jones' debut studio album Snacks (Supersize) was released on 6 September 2019.

[[Swashbuckler (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 movies, 1970s adventure movies, 1970s romance movies, American adventure movies

Swashbuckler is a 1976 American romantic adventure movie directed by James Goldstone and stars Robert Shaw, James Earl Jones, Peter Boyle, Geneviève Bujold, Beau Bridges, Anjelica Huston. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was a box office bomb.

[[Roy Lester]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American football coaches, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Sportspeople from West Virginia, Sportspeople from Maryland

E. Roy Lester (1923 – May 3, 2020) was an American college and high school football coach. He was born in Spencer, West Virginia. He played for West Virginia from 1947 to 1949. He also coached Richard Montgomery High School and the Maryland Terrapins.

Lester died in Rockville, Maryland on May 3, 2020 of COVID-19, aged 96.

[[Young T & Bugsey]]

CATEGORIES: Musical duos, Musical groups established in 2010, 2010s British music groups, 2010 establishments in England

Young T & Bugsey (real names Rashard Tucker and Doyin Julius respectively) are an English rap duo. The members are Rashard Tucker (better known as Young T) and Doyin Julius (better known as Bugsey), who both grew up in Nottingham.

[[Spencer, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Spencer is a city in and the county seat of Roane County, West Virginia, United States. The population was 2,322 at the 2010 census.  

[[Roane County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Roane County is a county located in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 14,926. Its county seat is Spencer. The county was founded in 1856 and is named for Spencer Roane.

[[Selma Barkham]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, English historians, Canadian historians, Canadian scientists, Geographers, Scientists from London, Writers from London

Selma Huxley Barkham, OC, (née Huxley; 8 March 1927 – 4 May 2020) was an English-Canadian historian and geographer. Her works focused on the maritime history of Canada and of the Basque Country. She was born in London.

In 1981, she was awarded the Order of Canada for her work. A whaling port she discovered in Red Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador was declared a National Historic Site of Canada (1979) and a World Heritage Site by UNESCO (June 2013). 

She was made an Officer of the Order of Newfoundland and Labrador in 2015.

Barkham died on 4 May 2020 in Chichester, England at the age of 93.

[[Up! (1976 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Russ Meyer

Up! is a 1976 American adult comedy movie directed by Russ Meyer and starring Raven De La Croix, Kitten Natividad, Robert McLane. It was distributed by RM Films International.

[[John Hugh Seiradakis]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Greek scientists, Physicists, Astronomers

John Hugh Seiradakis (Greek: Ιωάννης-Χιου Σειραδάκης) (5 March 1948 – 3 May 2020) was a Greek astronomer and physicist. He was born in Chania, Greece. He was best known for his works in the understanding of radio pulsars, the galactic center and archaeoastronomy.

He was a founding member of the Hellenic Astronomical Society, the European Astronomical Society and the International Olympiad on Astronomy and Astrophysics (IOAA).

He worked at the University of Thessaloniki, Max Planck Institute for Radio Astronomy, University of Hamburg, University of California and at Victoria University of Manchester. 

Seiradakis died on May 3, 2020 in his home in Thessaloniki, Greece of problems caused by cancer, aged 72.

[[Ruy Guerra]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Portuguese writers, Brazilian movie directors, Brazilian screenwriters

Ruy Alexandre Guerra Coelho Pereira (born August 22, 1931) is a Portuguese-Brazilian movie director and screenwriter. He was born in Maputo, Portuguese Mozambique. He directed his first movie Os Cafajestes in 1962. 

In 1964, Guerra directed Os Fuzis and was entered into the 14th Berlin International Film Festival where it won the Silver Bear Extraordinary Jury Prize.

[[Sterling Hayden]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 1986 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Cancer deaths in California, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American military personnel of World War II, Spies, American novelists, Actors from New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey

Sterling Walter Hayden (born Sterling Relyea Walter; March 26, 1916 – May 23, 1986) was an American actor, author, and sailor. His best known roles were in John Huston's The Asphalt Jungle (1950), Nicholas Ray's Johnny Guitar (1954), and Stanley Kubrick's The Killing (1956). He also starred as General Jack D. Ripper in Kubrick's Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964).

[[Upper Montclair, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New Jersey, Unincorporated communities in New Jersey

Upper Montclair is a census-designated place (CDP), unincorporated community and neighborhood within Montclair in Essex County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population for the CDP was 11,565.

[[Nicholas Ray]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1979 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in New York City, American movie directors, Businesspeople from Wisconsin

Nicholas Ray (born Raymond Nicholas Kienzle Jr., August 7, 1911 – June 16, 1979) was an American movie director. He was best known for directing the movie Rebel Without a Cause.

Ray died on June 16, 1979 in New York City of lung cancer, aged 67.

[[Galesville, Wisconsin]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Wisconsin, Trempealeau County, Wisconsin

Galesville is a city in Trempealeau County, Wisconsin, United States. The population was 1,481 at the 2010 census.

[[Foxtrot (1976 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 drama movies, British drama movies, Mexican movies, Movies directed by Arturo Ripstein

Foxtrot, also known as The Far Side of Paradise, is a 1977 British Mexican movie directed by Arturo Ripstein and starring Peter O'Toole, Charlotte Rampling, Max von Sydow. It was distributed by New World Pictures.

[[Trempealeau County, Wisconsin]]

CATEGORIES: Trempealeau County, Wisconsin, 1850s establishments in Wisconsin, 1855 establishments in the United States

Trempealeau County (ˈ, TREM) is a county in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. As of the 2010 census, the population was 28,816. Its county seat is Whitehall.

[[Joe (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by John G. Avildsen, American independent movies

Joe is a 1970 American drama movie directed by John G. Avildsen and starring Susan Sarandon, Peter Boyle, Dennis Patrick, K Callan. It was distributed by Cannon Group and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1971.

[[Yellowbeard]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 comedy movies, British comedy movies, American comedy movies

Yellowbeard is a 1983 American British comedy movie directed by Mel Damski and starring Peter Boyle, Graham Chapman, Cheech Marin, Tommy Chong, Peter Cook, Martin Hewitt, Marty Feldman, Spike Milligan, Eric Idle, James Mason, John Cleese, Nigel Planer, Susannah York, Beryl Reid, David Bowie. It was distributed by Orion Pictures.

[[Leonardo Villar]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Deaths from heart failure, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors, Brazilian stage actors, People from São Paulo

Leonardo Villar (July 25, 1923 – July 3, 2020) was a Brazilian actor. He was born in Piracicaba, São Paulo. He was known for his role as Ze do Borro in the 1962 drama movie O Pagador de Promessas. He also starred in The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga (1965), Juego peligroso (1967), and Brave New Land (2000).

Villar died on July 3, 2020 at a hospital in São Paulo from cardiac arrest caused by heart failure, aged 96.

[[Glória Menezes]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors

Glória Menezes, artistic name of Nicelde Soares Magalhães (born October 19, 1934) is a Brazilian actress. She was born in Pelotas, Rio Grande do Sul. Menezes was best known for her role as Amelia in the telenovela Páginas da Vida. 

From 1962 until his death in 2021, she was married to actor Tarcísio Meira. They have one child.

[[Tarcísio Meira]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, People from São Paulo, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors

Tarcísio Magalhães Sobrinho, usually known as Tarcísio Meira (October 5, 1935 – August 12, 2021) was a Brazilian actor. He was born in São Paulo, Brazil. He was one of the first actors to work in the most popular Brazilian channel Globo. His best known roles were as Military Christ in The Age of the Earth (1980) and as Ulisses in I Love You (1981).

In 1962, Meira married actress Glória Menezes. They had one child. Meira died at a hospital in São Paulo from COVID-19 on August 12, 2021 at the age of 85.

[[Othon Bastos]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors

Othon Bastos (born 23 May 1933) is a Brazilian movie actor. He has appeared in 50 movies since 1962. He was born in Tucano, Bahia. 

His best known roles were in O Pagador de Promessas (1962), Black God, White Devil (1964), Antonio das Mortes (1969), Of Gods and the Undead (1970), S. Bernardo (1972), The Last Plantation (1976), Heart and Guts (1982), Four Days in September (1997), Central Station (1998), Villa-Lobos - Uma Vida de Paixão (2000), Behind the Sun (2001), Nosso Lar (2010) and Os Experientes (2016).

[[Danuza Leão]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Models, Columnists, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian writers

Danuza Leão (born July 26, 1933) is a Brazilian model, socialite, journalist, writer, and actress. She was born in Itaguaçu, Espírito Santo. She worked as a columnist in Folha de S.Paulo. She had a minor role at Glauber Rocha's 1967 FIPRESCI Award winning movie Entranced Earth. 

She is the older sister of singer Nara Leão and was married to Samuel Wainer, founder of the newspaper Última Hora.

[[Lorne Munroe]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American cellists, Canadian musicians, People from Winnipeg

Lorne Munroe (November 24, 1924 – May 4, 2020) was an Canadian-American cellist. He was principal cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra from 1951 to 1964 and principal cellist of the New York Philharmonic from 1964 to 1996. He retired in 1996. Munroe was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Munroe died on May 4, 2020 at the age of 95.

[[Fort Yuma]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by Lesley Selander

Fort Yuma is a 1955 American western movie directed by Lesley Selander and starring Peter Graves, Joan Vohs, John Hudson, Joan Taylor. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Desk Set]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 comedy movies, 1950s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Walter Lang

Desk Set is a 1957 American romantic comedy movie directed by Walter Lang and based on the 1955 play of the same name by William Marchant. It stars Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn, Gig Young, Joan Blondell, Dina Merrill and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Island in the Sun (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s romance movies, American romance movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Robert Rossen

Island in the Sun is a 1957 American romance movie directed by Robert Rossen and based on the 1955 novel of the same name by Alec Waugh. It stars James Mason, Harry Belafonte, Joan Fontaine, Joan Collins, Dorothy Dandridge, Diana Wynyard, Basil Sydney, Patricia Owens and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has caused a larger effect more than the disease itself. As the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread around the globe, many people have begun to think about the economic effects such as the decreased business and unemployment. The pandemic caused the largest global recession in history, with more than a third of the global population at the time being placed on lockdown.

[[Kattode]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Pathanamthitta district

Kattode is a village in Pathanamthitta district, Kerala state,India.

[[Three Young Texans]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by Henry Levin

Three Young Texans is a 1954 American western movie directed by Henry Levin and starring Mitzi Gaynor, Keefe Brasselle, Jeffrey Hunter, Harvey Stephens, Aaron Spelling. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Isolation (health care)]]

CATEGORIES: Nursing

In hospitals or health care areas, isolation is one of the many measures that can be taken to stop the spread of certain diseases as it would lower the amount of people being infected by it. The most recent case are people being forced by law to stay at home as schools and jobs are closed due to the 2020 coronavirus pandemic. This is different than quarantine as this is for people who have not been infected.

[[COVID-19 recession]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic

The coronavirus recession, also known as the Great Lockdown or Great Shutdown, was a major global economic recession affecting the world economy in 2020 during and as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

[[COVID-19 misinformation]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic

The pandemic has caused a large number of conspiracy theories and misinformation about where the pandemic started, how serious it is and the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

[[Remdesivir]]

CATEGORIES: Drugs, COVID-19 pandemic

Remdesivir is a broad-spectrum antiviral medication created by the biopharmaceutical company Gilead Sciences. It was designed to treat Ebola.

As of 2020, remdesivir is being tested as a specific treatment for COVID-19. It is being used for the sickest of patients during the pandemic. It may shorten the time it takes to recover from the infection. Treatment is given by injection into a vein.

On May 1, the United States Food and Drug Administration gave doctors permission to use remdesivir on patients with COVID-19.  Ordinarily, the FDA would test remdesivir first to see if it worked on patients with COVID-19, but because of the COVID-19 pandemic, they told doctors they could start using the drug before the tests were finished.

In October 2020, the National Institutes of Health told the world the results of its tests: They studied 11,000 people and found that remdesivir did not help keep COVID-19 patients alive.  Gilead and some scientists said the results of the tests might not be correct.

CSI may refer to:

[[Dar Yasin]]

CATEGORIES: Indian journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners

Dar Yasin is a Indian Photo Journaist. He has been awarded Pulitzer Prize for his extensive cover on the Kashmir conflict.

[[Ciro Pessoa]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, People with cancer, Brazilian singers, Brazilian poets, Brazilian musicians, Guitarists, Songwriters, People from São Paulo

Ciro Pessoa Mendes Corrêa (June 12, 1957 – May 5, 2020), also known by his Dharma name Tenzin Chöpel, was a Brazilian singer-songwriter, guitarist, and poet. He was known as one of the founding members of the influential rock band Titãs and for his later work with post-punk/gothic rock band Cabine C. He was born in São Paulo, São Paulo.

Pessoa, who had cancer, died of COVID-19 in São Paulo on May 5, 2020 at the age of 62.

[[Didi Kempot]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indonesian singers, Indonesian writers, Singer-songwriters, Asian philanthropists

Didik Prasetyo, known as Didi Kempot (31 December 1966 – 5 May 2020) was an Indonesian singer-songwriter and philanthropist. He was born in Surakarta, Central Java. 

In 1989 he released his debut album. A few years later he had his breakthrough with the singles "Stasiun Balapan" and "Sewu Kutho". He was known as "The Godfather of the Broken-Hearted". In 2020, he wrote the song "Ojo Mudik" and gave a concert livestreame from his house. It raised $500,000 for the fight against coronavirus disease 2019. 

Kempot died of cardiac arrest on 5 May 2020 in Surakarta, aged 53.

[[Taufiq Kiemas]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, First Ladies and Gentlemen of Indonesia

Muhammad Taufiq Kiemas (31 December 1942 – 8 June 2013) was the Speaker of the People's Consultative Assembly of Indonesia from 2009 until his death in 2013. Taufiq (sometimes spelt Taufik) was the husband of Megawati Sukarnoputri, President of Indonesia from 2001 to 2004.

Kiemas died on 8 June 2013 in Singapore General Hospital, Singapore after a heart attack, aged 70.

[[Mark Beech (writer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths in the United Kingdom, British journalists, Critics, Writers from London

Mark Beech FRSA (1959 – 24 April 2020) was a British author, journalist and broadcaster. He was best known for his two books on the origins of names in rock music, and for his columns about music and the arts. 

Beech was the editor of DANTE magazine. A fellow of the UK Royal Society of Arts.

He died in Edinburgh of heart disease on 24 April 2020, aged 60.

[[Tinley Park, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois

Tinley Park is a village located in Cook County, Illinois, United States, with a small portion in Will County. The population was 56,703 at the 2010 census. It is one of the fastest growing suburbs southwest of Chicago. 

In 2009, Tinley Park was selected by BusinessWeek as the best place to raise a family in America.  In 2017, Tinley Park was listed as one of the 50 safest cities in America.

[[Nokia 5730 XpressMusic]]

CATEGORIES: Nokia mobile phones

The Nokia 5730 XpressMusic is a smartphone announced on March 11, 2009. It has a full backlit slide-out QWERTY keyboard, dedicated camera, volume, gaming keys, music keys, Wi-Fi (801.2b/g) connectivity, and a basic accelerometer that automatically rotates the screen into a landscape mode or portrait mode. It runs on Nokia's Symbian OS v9.3 S60 mobile phone platform. It is very similar to the Nokia E75, except it is designed to be used to play music.

The screen is a 2.4" TFT (measured diagonally) with a 240 by 320 pixel QVGA resolution. Earphones can be used using a 3.5mm audio jack, and the device is available with a pink, red, blue or silver trim. An Ovi web application is pre-installed. Ovi is Nokia's online services platform, featuring games, music, videos, phone apps, media sharing and social networking.

Like many phones in its price range, it has a 3.15-megapixel camera (with Carl-Zeiss optics, LED flash and 30fps VGA recording), and network-guided A-GPS. The N-Gage gaming platform can be used, allowing users to trial, purchase and play N-Gage 2.0 games, all of which can be done using the application. The device fully supports 3.5G, allowing mobile internet, voicemail, video calling and email to run at speeds of up to 7.2 MB/s. Uniquely,May 2015 if it is connected to a PC or laptop, it can use an available network to be a wireless broadband modem.May 2015

The device can be used to make, read, and to a limited extent, edit files (only in an editor's version) from Microsoft Word, PowerPoint and Excel. PDF files can be viewed using Adobe Reader LE 1.5.0, and RealPlayer is included so videos can be streamed (such as by using YouTube).

[[History of Ireland]]

CATEGORIES: Pages created with the Article Wizard from 2020, History of Ireland

The history of Ireland is the story of its past. Ireland is now divided into the Republic of Ireland, and Northern Ireland which is part of the United Kingdom. People began farming on Ireland thousands of years ago. The Celts moved there about 2,500 years ago. Ireland was divided into many small kingdoms. When Christians arrived, most Irish people became Christian. The Vikings and later the Normans invaded in the Middle Ages. Eventually, Ireland became part of the United Kingdom, with Great Britain. In the 1920s, most of Ireland became a separate country, but Northern Ireland stayed in the United Kingdom.

[[Practical High School]]

Practical High School Sikatiya, a school in Sikatiya, Siwan, Bihar, India. It was established in 1941 during british raj or six year before indian independence as a private school by late. Saryug Saran Dev but after a period, He handed it over to Bihar Government and it affiliated to the Bihar School Examination Board, Patna, Bihar but, still counted as one of the old schools in Maharajaganj block of Siwan district. The School code as per Bihar Education Government is 92096. late. Saryug Saran Dev was the first principal and also the founder of school. But at present time Mr. Rajeshwar Singh is the Principal of this school.

[[Yemenite architecture]]

CATEGORIES: Yemen, Architecture

Yemenite architecture  is the name of the Architecture style of Yemen from the Pre-Islamic period until the Islamic period.  today. Particularly notable in this style is the design of the buildings in which Islam began to spread in this country. This style of architecture is mainly characterized by the construction of mud bricks and residential buildings in the form of tall towers and sometimes even large boulders intertwined between dwellings. in southern Saudi Arabia some of villages close to the border of Yemen are having an architectural style similar to Yemen.

[[My Cousin Rachel (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 movies, 1950s romance movies, 1950s mystery movies, American mystery movies, American romance movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Henry Koster

My Cousin Rachel is a 1952 American romantic mystery movie directed by Henry Koster and based on the 1951 novel of the same name by Daphne du Maurier. It stars Olivia de Havilland, Richard Burton, Audrey Dalton, Ronald Squire, George Dolenz and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 4 Academy Awards in 1953.

[[You Can't Run Away from It]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 comedy movies, 1950s musical movies, American musical movies, American comedy movies

You Can't Run Away from It is a 1956 American musical comedy movie directed by Dick Powell and starring June Allyson, Jack Lemmon, Charles Bickford, Jim Backus, Allyn Joslyn, Henry Youngman, The Four Aces. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Raintree County]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s romance movies, American romance movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Edward Dmytryk

Raintree County is a 1957 American romance movie directed by Edward Dmytryk and based on the 1948 novel of the same name by Ross Lockridge Jr.. It stars Elizabeth Taylor, Montgomery Clift, Eva Marie Saint, Lee Marvin, Rod Taylor, Walter Abel and were distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for four Academy Awards in 1958.

[[Guadalupe bass]]

CATEGORIES: Centrarchidae, IUCN Red List data deficient species, Near threatened species, Perciformes

The Guadelupe bass (Micropterus treculii) is a popular gamefish in China, these creatures can only be found in fish tanks at Chinese fast food restaurants, or in rare cases, sewage pipes.

[[Blackboard Jungle]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard Brooks

Blackboard Jungle is a 1955 American drama movie directed by Richard Brooks and based on the novel of the same name by Evan Hunter. It stars Glenn Ford, Sidney Poitier, Vic Morrow, Anne Francis, Louis Calhern, Paul Mazursky, Jamie Farr and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for four Academy Awards.

[[The Adventures of Quentin Durward]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 movies, 1950s adventure movies, American adventure movies, British adventure movies, Movies directed by Richard Thorpe

The Adventures of Quentin Durward, also known as Quentin Durward, is a 1955 British American adventure movie directed by Richard Thorpe and based on the 1923 novel of the same name by Sir Walter Scott. It stars Robert Taylor, George Cole, Kay Kendall, Robert Morley, John Carson, Harcourt Williams and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[La Bréole]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Alpes-de-Haute-Provence

[[Ubaye-Serre-Ponçon]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Alpes-de-Haute-Provence

Ubaye-Serre-Ponçon is a commune in the department of Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, southeastern France. It was formed on 1 January 2017 from the merger of the former communes of La Bréole (the seat) and Saint-Vincent-les-Forts.

[[The Year of Living Dangerously (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, 1980s war movies, Australian drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Peter Weir

The Year of Living Dangerously is a 1982 Australian American romantic drama movie and was based on the novel of the same name by Christopher Koch. When journalist Guy Hamilton (Mel Gibson) arrives in Jakarta, Indonesia, he has difficulty making contacts. He forms a friendship with dwarf photographer Billy Kwan (Linda Hunt), through whom he meets British diplomat Jill Bryant (Sigourney Weaver). Bryant falls for Hamilton, and she gives him key information about an approaching Communist uprising. As the city becomes more dangerous, Hamilton stays to pursue the story. However, he faces more threats as he gets closer to the government.

Release date: January 21, 1983 (USA)

Director: Peter Weir

Music composed by: Maurice Jarre

Awards: Academy Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role, More

Screenplay: Peter Weir, David Williamson, Christopher Koch

[[Crossfire (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Edward Dmytryk

Crossfire is a 1947 American crime drama movie directed by Edward Dmytryk and based on the 1945 novel The Brick Foxhole by Richard Brooks. It stars Robert Young, Robert Mitchum, Robert Ryan, Gloria Grahame, Paul Kelly, Sam Levene, Lex Barker and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures. It was nominated for 5 Academy Awards in 1948.

Castellane is a commune in the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence department in southeastern France. With about 1,600 people, Castellane is the least-populated sub-prefecture in France.

[[Zarina (artist)]]

CATEGORIES: Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Indian artists, American artists, Naturalized citizens of the United States, 1937 births, 2020 deaths

Zarina Hashmi (16 July 1937 – 25 April 2020), known professionally as Zarina, was an Indian-American artist and printmaker. She worked in New York City. Her work focused in drawing, printmaking, and sculpture. Her works were involved with the Minimalist movement. She was born in Aligarh, United Provinces, British Raj. Zarina was a board member of the New York Feminist Art Institute.

Zarina died in London from problems of Alzheimer's disease on 25 April 2020, aged 83.

[[Renee Amoore]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, American political activists, American physicians, Scientists from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, People from Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

Renee Amoore R.N. (January 24, 1953 – May 5, 2020) was an American health care activist and politician. She was the founder and president of The Amoore Group, Inc. Amoore was born in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania. She was elected to Pennsylvania's Republican State Committee in 1992 and became its deputy chair in 1996.

Amoore spoke on the third night of the Republican National Convention on September 3, 2008.

Amoore died on May 5, 2020 in Philadelphia, aged 67.

[[Kiing Shooter]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, 2020 deaths, American rap musicians from New York, American songwriters, Writers from New York City, American hip hop musicians, Musicians from New York City, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

William Daniels (yes – yes), better known by his stage name Kiing Shooter, was an American rapper and songwriter. He was born in New York City. 

Kiing Shooter first known for his works with fellow rapper Dave East, after releasing many freestyles in 2017. Kiing Shooter became known with his single "They Say" which was released on June 29, 2018. He released his debut EP "Fucc The Doubters" on August 24, 2018, with features from Dave East, Don Q and Mac and it peaked at 148 on the US Billboard 200. 

Kiing Shooter died on May 5, 2020 of COVID-19 at the age of 24.

[[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program]]

CATEGORIES: World War II

The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program under the Civil Affairs and Military Government Sections of the Allied armies was created in 1943 to help protect cultural property in war areas during and after World War II. 

The group of about 400 service members and civilians worked with military forces to protect and save historic and cultural monuments from war damage. They also tried to find and return works of art and other items of cultural importance that had been stolen by the Nazis.

Many of the men and women of the MFAA, also known as Monuments Men.

[[Alfred "Uganda" Roberts]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, American funk musicians, Deaths from lung cancer, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana

Alfred "Uganda" Roberts  (April 8, 1943 – May 5, 2020) was an American conga-percussion player. She was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. As a young musician he performed with Professor Longhair. He would continue to work with until Longhair's death. He also performed with Dr. John. 

Roberts died in New Orleans on May 5, 2020 of lung cancer, aged 77.

[[Michael McClure]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, American poets, American playwrights, American songwriters, American critics, American novelists, Writers from Kansas, Writers from San Francisco

Michael McClure (October 20, 1932 – May 4, 2020) was an American poet, playwright, critic, songwriter, and novelist. He became known as one of the five poets (including Allen Ginsberg) who read at the famous San Francisco Six Gallery reading in 1955. 

He was one of the inspirations for Jack Kerouac's The Dharma Bums. He soon became a key member of the Beat Generation. A character named "Pat McLear" is inspired by him in Kerouac's Big Sur.

McClure was born in Marysville, Kansas. He studied at Municipal University of Wichita, the University of Arizona and San Francisco State College. He spent his career in San Francisco.

McClure died of stroke-related problems on May 4, 2020 in Oakland, California, aged 87.

[[Bill Parcells]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, People from Englewood, New Jersey, Detroit Lions players, American football coaches, Sportspeople from New Jersey

Duane Charles "Bill" Parcells (born August 22, 1941), also known as "The Big Tuna", is an American football coach. He was a head coach in the National Football League (NFL) for 19 seasons. 

He is best known as the head coach of the New York Giants, which he led to two Super Bowl titles. Parcells later was the head coach of the New England Patriots, New York Jets, and Dallas Cowboys.

For a short time, he played for the Detroit Lions in 1964.

Parcells was born in Englewood, New Jersey. He studied at Wichita State University.

[[Haworth, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Haworth (h HAH-worth) is a borough in Bergen County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the borough's population was 3,382.

[[China Gate (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s action movies, American action movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Samuel Fuller

China Gate is a 1957 American action movie directed and written by Samuel Fuller and starring Gene Barry, Angie Dickinson, Nat King Cole, Lee Van Cleef, George Givot. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Angela Nicole Walker]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, American political activists, 2020 United States vice-presidential candidates, Green Party of the United States politicians, Politicians from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Politicians from South Carolina

Angela Nicole Walker (born January 19, 1974) is an American school bus driver and labor organizer. Walker is the vice-presidential nominee of the Socialist Party USA for the 2020 election. She is also Howie Hawkins' running mate for the Green Party nomination. They were the vice-presidential nominee of the Socialist Party USA for the 2016 election. 

Walker previously ran in 2014 as an independent socialist for sheriff of Milwaukee County, Wisconsin. In May 2020, a Green Party candidate for President, Howie Hawkins, announced that Walker was his choice for running-mate.

[[Doug Collins (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, United States representatives from Georgia, State legislators of the United States, US Republican Party politicians

Douglas Allen Collins (born August 16, 1966) is an American politician. He was the United States Representative from Georgia's 9th congressional district from 2013 to 2021. He was a Republican member of the Georgia House of Representatives.

In 2020, he announced his candidacy for the 2020 U.S. Senate election, challenging incumbent Republican Senator Kelly Loeffler. He came in last place, losing to both Loeffler and to Democrat Raphael Warnock.

[[Gainesville, Georgia]]

The city of Gainesville is the county seat of Hall County, Georgia, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 33,804.

It stars Spencer Tracy, Robert Ryan, Anne Francis, Dean Jagger, Walter Brennan, Ernest Borgnine, Lee Marvin and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 1956.

[[St. Lunatics]]

CATEGORIES: Hip hop bands, Musical groups established in 1993, Musical quintets, 1990s American music groups, 1991 establishments in the United States

The St. Lunatics are a rap crew from St. Louis that was runned by rapper Nelly and comprised of his hometown buddies Ali, Murphy Lee, Kyjuan, City Spud, and Slo'Down, who left. They were formed in 1993 and came out with their local hit "Gimme What U Got" in 1996. Then, they bursted on the music scene with Nelly with the release of his solo album Country Grammar but City Spud was arrested and sentenced to 10 years in prison for robbery. So far away from the members of St. Lunatics, Nelly introduced the world to his crew when the crew released their debut album Free City in 2001 with hits such as "Summer In The City" and "Midwest Swing". Then Ali released his solo album Heavy Starch in 2002 and Murphy Lee released his solo album Murphy's Law in 2003.

[[Tourniquet]]

CATEGORIES: Emergency medicine, Medical equipment

A tightly-compressed bandage used to stop bleeding by stopping the flow of blood through a large artery in a limb.

It could be made from clothing materials or any other material depending on what is available

[[Kasia Urbaniak]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, American businesspeople, American educators

Kasia Urbaniak (born 1978) is a teacher, businesswomen and founder of The Academy. She was born in New York City. She is the daughter of jazz musicians Michal Urbaniak and Urszula Dudziak.

[[Bruh]]

Bruh can mean:

[[Michal Urbaniak]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Jazz composers, Polish people, Violinists

Michał Urbaniak (born January 22, 1943) is a Polish jazz musician. He plays violin, lyricon, and saxophone. His music includes elements of folk music, rhythm and blues, hip hop, and symphonic music.

[[Urszula Dudziak]]

Urszula Bogumiła Dudziak-Urbaniak (born 22 October 1943) is a Polish jazz vocalist. She has worked with Krzysztof Komeda, Michał Urbaniak (her ex-husband), Gil Evans, Archie Shepp, and Lester Bowie. In 2007, her 1970s song "Papaya" gained widespread popularity in Asia and Latin America.

Dudziak was born in Straconka which is now a neighborhood of Bielsko-Biała in Poland. She studied piano, but began to sing in the late 50s after hearing records by Ella Fitzgerald. Within a few years she became one of the most popular jazz artists in Poland. She met and later married Michał Urbaniak. 

[[Sicarii]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient history, Assassins, History of Israel, Jewish denominations, Jewish history, Roman Empire, Secret societies, Terrorism

Sicarii were killers who were a splinter group of the Zealots during the time leading up to the destruction of Jerusalem by the Roman General Titus. Their name derives from a work that means "dagger". They hid in groups of people who supported Roman rule and then pulled their daggers and killed people. Then they ran away and hid. Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus in the New Testament, was believed by some to be a sicarius.

[[Tennessee Democratic Party]]

CATEGORIES: Political parties in the United States, Tennessee

The Tennessee Democratic Party is the Tennessee affiliate of the Democratic Party.

[[Souls (series)]]

CATEGORIES: Video games, Role-playing video games

The Souls series is a series of action RPGs made by Hidetaka Miyazaki and FromSoftware. The games in the series are Demon's Souls and the three Dark Souls games. King's Field, Bloodborne, and Sekiro are similarly made games also made by From Software, but they not part of the series. The games are made cheaply, which allowed the games to make a lot of money even if they did not sell as well as some other games. Below are the features in all the games.

[[Dark Souls]]

CATEGORIES: Video games, Role-playing video games, PlayStation 3 games, Xbox 360 games

Dark Souls is an action RPG made by Hidetaka Miyazaki and FromSoftware. It is the sequel to Demon's Souls.

The game is very similar to its prequel, but there were also many changes made.

Dark Souls became successful and FromSoftware made had two sequels and two spiritual successors, Bloodborne and Sekiro. The game became so popular that other video game companies made high difficulty action RPG's similar to Dark Souls.

[[Oxygen therapy]]

CATEGORIES: Medicine

Oxygen therapy, also called supplemental oxygen, is when oxygen gas (O2) is used for medical treatment by giving the gas to the patient for inhalation. It can be used for ilnesses like  hypoxia, carbon monoxide toxicity, and cluster headaches. It can be used over a long time for people who suffer with illnesses that lower oxygen levels in the blood like COPD and cystic fibrosis. It can be given in a few different ways such as through a nasal cannula, face mask, or inside a hyperbaric chamber. Oxygen levels need to be high enough for respiration to keep a patient healthy and for normal cell metabolism.

[[Urban structure]]

CATEGORIES: Urban and regional sciences

Urban structure It is the order of organization of planning areas and of land use within the cities and sometimes even smaller towns.

[[Together at Home]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic, Concerts

Together at Home (also known as One World: Together at Home) was a virtual concert series organised by Global Citizen and curated by singer Lady Gaga, in support of the World Health Organization. 

[[The Wackiest Ship In the Army]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 comedy movies, American comedy movies, World War II movies

The Wackiest Ship In the Army is a 1960 American World War II comedy movie directed by Richard Murphy and based on the 1956 story Big Fella Wash-Wash by Herbert Carlson. It stars Jack Lemmon, Ricky Nelson, Chips Rattray, Tom Tully, John Lund and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was made into a TV series in 1965.

[[An Affair to Remember]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s romance movies, American romance movies, American movie remakes, Movies directed by Leo McCarey

An Affair to Remember is a 1957 American romance movie directed by Leo McCarey and starring Cary Grant, Deborah Kerr, Richard Denning, Neva Patterson, Cathleen Nesbitt. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for 4 Academy Awards in 1958. It is a remake of the 1939 movie Love Affair.

[[Forty Guns]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Samuel Fuller

Forty Guns is a 1957 American western movie directed by Samuel Fuller and starring Barbara Stanwyck, Barry Sullivan, Gene Barry, Robert Dix, Dean Jagger, John Ericson, Chuck Hayward, Chuck Roberson. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Demon's Souls]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 video games, Role-playing video games, PlayStation 3 games, PlayStation 3-only games

Demon's Souls is an action RPG on the Playstation 3 video game console made by Hidetaka Miyazaki and FromSoftware. It is the first game in the Souls series of video games. It is known for being a very hard game. Its difficulty was liked and disliked by many people. The gameplay has some similar features to FromSfotware's earlier game, King's Field, like exploring for armor and weapons, having a high difficulty, and having timing-based fighting, but it is different because Demon's Souls has a third-person point of view.

The idea of the game was created some time before the game came out, but many workers in FromSoftware did not think the game would be popular. However, when Miyazaki began working for From, he picked up the project and made Demon's Souls into a game. Since From was a little-known video game developer and they thought the game would not sell well anyway, From had a lot of freedom of making the game they wanted to make, as they did not have to remove a lot of features to please video game publishers. Surprisingly, Demon's Souls sold many more copies and became much more popular than From thought. It would be popular enough to make three sequels and two spiritual successors, Bloodborne and Sekiro.

[[Rockabilly Baby]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by William F. Claxton

Rockabilly Baby is a 1957 American musical movie directed by William F. Claxton and starring Virginia Field, Douglas Kennedy, Irene Ryan, Ellen Corby, Frank Sully, Marlene Willis. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[FromSoftware]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 establishments in Japan, Video game companies, Companies of Japan, Tokyo

FromSoftware, Inc. is a Japanese video game developer that made video games like the Souls series, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. Games that the company made before the Souls series include the King's Field series and the Armored Core series. The company has been lead by Hidetaka Miyazaki, the leader of the Demon's Souls team, since Demon's Souls became popular.

[[Hidetaka Miyazaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Japanese artists, Japanese video game designers, Living people, People from Shizuoka Prefecture

Hidetaka Miyazaki is the leader of the video game company FromSoftware and head designer games such as Demon's Souls, Dark Souls, Dark Souls 3, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. Miyazaki grew up in a poor family. Miyazaki loved reading, but since his family could not even afford to buy books for him, he would often borrow them from the library. Although he loved reading, there were parts of the books he read that he could not understand, so he just made up parts of the story in his own mind. This would be the way stories in the Souls series of video games, which he would later make, are told. In those games, some details are told to the player, but the player is expected to imagine the parts of the story not told.

After university, Miyazaki would be an account manager for the US company Oracle Corporation until he was 29. This was because after playing the game Ico, he decided to quit his job to become a game designer. Due to his age and lack of experience, very few companies would hire him. However, he got a job from FromSoftware and became the leading designer for some of the Armored Core games. While FromSoftware had ideas for Demon's Souls, the idea was put away because no one thought the game would be popular. However, Miyazaki liked the idea and lead the development team. Demon's Souls would become so popular that FromSoftware would become a well-known video game company, and Miyazaki would later take over the company.

[[Johnny Apollo (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s crime movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

Johnny Apollo is a 1940 American crime drama movie directed by Henry Hathaway and starring Tyrone Power, Dorothy Lamour, Edward Arnold, Lloyd Nolan. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Heritage of the Desert (1932 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 movies, 1930s western movies, American western movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

Heritage of the Desert is a 1932 American western movie directed by Henry Hathaway and is based on the novel of the same name by Zane Grey and is the second version of the novel. It stars Randolph Scott, Sally Blane, J. Farrell MacDonald, David Landau and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[The Big Trail]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 movies, 1930s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by Raoul Walsh

The Big Trail is a 1930 American romantic western movie directed by Raoul Walsh and starring John Wayne, Marguerite Churchill, Tyrone Power, Sr., El Brendel, Tully Marshall, Frederick Burton, Ian Keith. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Cherry, Harry & Raquel!]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Russ Meyer

Cherry, Harry & Raquel! is a 1969 American action comedy movie directed by Russ Meyer and starring Charles Napier, Larissa Ely, Linda Ashton, Uschi Digard. It was distributed by Panamint Films.

[[Casa Grande, Arizona]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Arizona

Casa Grande (O'odham: Wainom Wo:g) is a city in Pinal County, halfway between Phoenix and Tucson in the U.S. state of Arizona.The population of the city is 57,232 as of 2018. "Casa Grande" is Spanish for "big house".

[[Millie Small]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Jamaican singers, Songwriters

Millicent Dolly May Small CD (6 October 1946 – 5 May 2020) was a Jamaican singer-songwriter. She was best known for her 1964 song "My Boy Lollipop". It reached number two in both the UK Singles Chart and the US Billboard Hot 100. She was born in Clarendon, Jamaica.

Small died on 5 May 2020 of a stroke in London, aged 73.

[[My Boy Lollipop]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 songs, 1964 songs

"My Boy Lollipop" (originally "My Girl Lollypop") is a song written in the mid-1950s by Robert Spencer of the doo-wop group The Cadillacs.  It was first recorded in New York in 1956 by Barbie Gaye. A later version, recorded in 1964 by Jamaican teenager Millie Small, with very similar rhythm, became one of the top selling ska songs of all time.

[[Nahum Rabinovitch]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli rabbis, People from Montreal

Rabbi Nahum Eliezer Rabinovitch (נחום אליעזר רבינוביץ'; 1928 – May 6, 2020) was a Canadian-born Israeli Orthodox rabbi and posek. He was the head of Yeshivat Birkat Moshe in Ma'ale Adumim. He was born in Montreal, Canada. In 2015 he led the Giyur K'halacha conversion court, of which he was one of the founders.

Rabinovitch died on May 6, 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Florian Schneider]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Germany, German pop singers, Guitarists, Violinists, Saxophonists, German pianists, Drummers, German pop musicians, Electronic musicians, People from Baden-Württemberg

Florian Schneider-Esleben (7 April 1947  21 April 2020) was a German electronic pop singer and musician. He was best known as one of the founding members of the electronic band Kraftwerk. He was born in present-day Baden-Württemberg, Germany.

David Bowie named a song after Schneider in 1977. Schneider retired in 2008, but then came back in 2014 then officially retiring a year later.

Schneider died from cancer on 21 April 2020 in Düsseldorf at the age of 73.

[[Dmitry Bosov]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Suicides by firearm, Russian businesspeople, Billionaires

Dmitry Borisovich Bosov (Дмитрий Борисович Босов; March 27, 1968 — May 6, 2020) was a Russian businessman. He was the founder, majority shareholder and Chairman of the Board of Directors of ALLTECH Group. He was Head of Supervisory Board of HC Sibir Novosibirsk from 2008 until his death. He was born in Barnaul, Altai Krai, then Soviet Union.

In 2019, he was ranked 102nd in the Forbes list of richest businessmen in Russia, with a fortune of 950 million dollars. In 2020, he was ranked 1851st in the Forbes list of world’s billionaires, with a fortune of 1.1 billion dollars.

Bosov shot himself on May 6, 2020 at his mansion in Usovo, Moscow Oblast at the age of 52.

CATEGORIES: 1922 movies, 1920s romance movies, 1920s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books

It stars Rudolph Valentino, Wanda Hawley, Charles Ogle, Fanny Midgley, Josef Swickard, J. Farrell MacDonald, George Field and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[VRML]]

CATEGORIES: Internet, Computer file formats, ISO standards, Graphics, Computing

VRML (Virtual Reality Modeling Language, pronounced vermal, or by its initials, known before 1995 as Virtual Reality Markup Language) is a standard 3-dimensional (3D) interactive vector graphics file format designed for the World Wide Web. It has been succeeded by X3D.

[[Wrabel]]

CATEGORIES: American pop singers, American songwriters, Living people, 1989 births

Stephen Wrabel (born 7 January 1989), better known as just Wrabel, is an American singer, songwriter, and musician. He is based in Los Angeles and is signed to Epic Records. Wrabel was invited by Afrojack to perform a song live during Afrojack's show. The track featured Wrabel's vocals and piano playing titled "Ten Feet Tall" and resulted in an international hit. The song was also premiered in the United States with the Bud Light commercial that aired during the 2014 Super Bowl XLVlll and was viewed by around 100 million viewers. This is Wrabel's first big charting hit. He released his debut album on Island Records in 2014.

[[Rock Mafia]]

CATEGORIES: American record producers, American songwriters, Musical groups established in the 2000s, 2000s American music groups, 2000s establishments in the United States

Rock Mafia are an American record production/songwriting team including Tim James, Antonina Armato, and Paul Palmer who writes songs from pop music/dance music/rock music artists, who are credited for contributing to some of the most successful pop artists since the early 2000s.

Rock Mafia's sound is a distinctive blend of dance, pop, and rock.

[[Girlicious]]

CATEGORIES: American pop music groups, American R&B bands, Musical groups disestablished in 2011, Musical groups established in 2007, Musical groups from Los Angeles, California, Musical quartets, 2000s American music groups, 2007 establishments in the United States, 2011 disestablishments in the United States

Girlicious are a girl group that is being host by Chelsea Korka, Melissa Reyes, and Melissa Smith. After all three have failed to become members 

of the Pussycat Dolls, they have decided to create their own group with the approval of Robin Antin. 

Unlike the search for the next member of Pussycat Dolls, there was more finalist chosen than just one. The time of when this was featured on television is still unknown as it was still being filmed. 

[[Jaykae]]

CATEGORIES: English rap musicians, Grime music artists, Living people, 1991 births

Jamun Khan (born 23 July 1991), better known by his stage name Jaykae, is an English grime MC and rapper. He was born in Small Heath, Birmingham, England. He performed grime music, hip hop music, and British hip hop. His musical career began in 2008. He is signed to Doing Bits Worldwide Limited and a record label of the same name as his stage name. He has worked with other artists like Stormzy.

[[Burna Boy]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic Records artists, Living people, Nigerian singers, Songwriters, 1991 births

Damini Ebunoluwa Ogulu (born 2 July 1991), better known by his stage name Burna Boy, is a Nigerian dancehall/reggae singer and songwriter. He was born in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. He performed afro-fusion, dancehall, and reggae. He plays the vocals. He started his musical career in 2010. He is signed to Spaceship, Bad Habit, Atlantic Records, and Warner Music Group.

Kent. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and won an Academy Award in 1930.

[[Today We Live]]

Today We Live is a 1933 American World War I romantic drama movie directed by Howard Hawks and is based on the 1932 story Turnabout by William Faulkner. It stars Joan Crawford, Gary Cooper, Robert Young, Franchot Tone and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
